dialogues.text: It's true, dear-heart, you've spoiled  me pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In exchange, we ask only that you  follow the rules. Now you know as  well as I do...you're not to entertain  visitors in your quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm entertaining you now, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a beautiful young prospect,  ripe for corruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so sure. COULMIER's amused in spite of himself. THE MARQUIS laughs too, only with a slightly sinister edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your pen in hand, Marquis. Purge  these wicked thoughts of yours on  paper; maybe they'll govern you less  in life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fill page after page, I promise. COULMIER raises his glass in a friendly toast:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swiftness of the COACH makes the ground quake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER reads from a large parchment scroll with a Royal wax Seal, newly-broken. VALCOUR stands by, anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got no right, sending someone  to sit on your shoulder.  I work for  you; I won't take orders from a  stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly; hiding  concern)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't worry, Valcour. It's  administrative, nothing more.

VALCOUR watches COULMIER, unconvinced, as the ABBE rolls the scroll, tucks it under his arm, and strolls among the PATIENTS, dressed in smocks and painting at easels. He ge chastises one LUNATIC who's chewing on his brush:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't eat the paint, Pascal. Next, he steps forward to inspect a painting by DAUPHIN, cheery fellow with severe burns on much of his face.  The canvas depicts a grisly scene; a desperate father shepher his children out of a burning house, his robes ablaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, Dauphin. It's far better to  paint fires than to set them, isn't  it? DAUPHIN grins, happy for COULMIER's approval. A joyous bu of the Papae Marcelli mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ROW OF HAUNTED, RUINED FACES. But--from deep in their s AN ASTONISHINGLY BEAUTIFUL SOUND, like a choir of angels. COULMIER conducts, jubilant. As the music soars, it seems transform--even redeem--the singers. MADELEINE watches-- admiringly--from the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RUMBLE of HOOVES. The DOCTOR's COACH--with its Gothic accoutrement--lurches into the drive. GAILLON hops off, a opens the door. ROYER-COLLARD disembarks. Emanating from  within, the EXHILARATING MUSIC. The DOCTOR and GAILLON  exchange a look; have they come to the right place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As COULMIER conducts, he notices several SINGERS are  distracted; they're staring past him, all the way down th nave. He turns to see ROYER-COLLARD, flanked by GAILLON a VALCOUR, in the doorway. VALCOUR shoots COULMIER a look t says "He's here." COULMIER turns, and silences the choir  with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all for today, thank-you. The CHOIR disperses. COULMIER bounds down the aisle, his outstretched in welcome. MADELEINE lingers, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Royer-Collard? May I be the first  to welcome you to Charenton--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This may feel a tad awkward, my  friend, but it needn't be. I've merely  come to oversee your work here;  understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a formality; truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a man of Science; I'm a man  of God. Charenton stands to profit  from us both, I'm certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need an office on the grounds;  someplace to store my things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hint of anxiety)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind my asking....why  has the Emperor taken such sudden  interest in my...our...affairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems a particular patient of  yours has captured his fancy.

dialogues.speaker: THE MARQUIS, VIEWED THROUGH THE PEEPHOLE OF HIS CELL DOOR
dialogues.text: He rails against the world:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, why, WHY should this be happening  to me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, gentleman! FRANVAL kneels before PITOU, holding a lady's satin shoe. PITOU--meanwhile--is preoccupied with his wig; a flowing  cascade of golden curls. Behind them, a tawdry back-drop
the French countryside.  FRANVAL wreaks havoc with his li reciting them in painfully sing-song fashion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm just a lowly cobbler, and I  have been all my life. But with this  shoe, I'm asking you to be a cobbler's  wife--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dreadful play, true!  A  festering pustule on the face of  literature.  Why the parchment it's  written upon isn't worthy to wipe my  ass! BUT YOU NEED NOT MAKE IT WORSE! Say your lines with conviction, ma  cherie! Like a true actor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not an actor; I'm a dyspeptic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seduce her, you goon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER and ROYER-COLLARD confer, en route to THE MARQUI CELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand he practices the very  crimes he preaches in his fiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few indiscretions in his youth. ROYER-COLLARD cocks an eyebrow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indiscretions, Abbe?  Please. I've  read his case history. At sixteen,  he violated a serving girl with a  crucifix. After six months in the  dungeon at Vincennes, he mutilated a  prostitute, cutting her flesh with a  razor, then cauterizing the wounds  with wax--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you'll judge him by his  progress here, and not his past  reputation.
THEY reach the cell door. ROYER-COLLARD gazes in at THE  MARQUIS as he would a creature at the zoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's made a great success of our  Little Theater; there's seldom an  empty seat.  Not to mention its  therapeutic value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing dress-up with cretins? That  sounds like a symptom of madness;  not its cure. Suddenly, THE MARQUIS rears up in the peephole to confron ROYER-COLLARD face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homo perversio, Doctor.  A species  that thrives in captivity. Their eyes meet; flicker of recognition passes between th Doppelgangers, meeting for the first time. COULMIER  interjects:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Royer-Collard; he's  joining us here in an... He looks to the DOCTOR for help:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...advisory capacity. The DOCTOR considers the word "advisory", then nods. THE  MARQUIS' eyebrow arches in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to our humble madhouse,  Doctor.  I trust you'll find yourself  at home. And with that, he slams the peephole shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER and ROYER-COLLARD make their way through the asy High above--along the railing of the grand staircase-- MADELEINE appears, flanked by MICHETTE and CHARLOTTE. The come to size up the new DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he in your care, and not a  proper prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife's influence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better to have an insane spouse than  a criminal one. Whispers from the GIRLS above; COULMIER shoots MADELEINE look that says "behave yourself."  She watches the TWO ME turn the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's never once attempted escape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man of his notoriety? He wouldn't  last a day on the streets without  capture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUNS tend PATIENTS with various maladies; others mash her A PHRENOLOGIST uses pincers to measure a PATIENT's scalp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, every wholesome thing he  might desire, he has at Charenton. A  library, filled with the world's  great books, music lessons, watercolor  exercises--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the impact of all these  amenities upon his psyche?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He no longer roars or spits. He no  longer taunts the guards or molests  his fellow wards--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his writing? COULMIER suppresses a tiny smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. That.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well....?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I's essential to his recovery; a  purgative for the toxins in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you favor its publication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For sale? To the general public?   Certainly not; it's unprintable. DR. ROYER-COLLARD reaches inside his jacket, and pulls ou copy of Justine. He hands it to the ABBE, who's dumbfound COULMIER starts to scan the pages; the unmistakable prose you-know-who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God... He looks up to see that the DOCTOR has moved on, strollin down the hall with authority. He races to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to believe me, I had no  idea--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All France is aghast at this book,  yet you've not heard of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've taken vows to live my life within  these walls; not outside them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbe, I admire you; I do. You've a  conviction...an idealism...peculiar  to the very young. And so I'll be  candid.  The Ministry has sent me  here with the most explicit...the  most severe instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAILLON, VALCOUR and ORVOLLE appear, bringing in parapher from the DOCTOR's carriage. A few items are particularly  menacing; a helmet for trephining; a wire sarcophagus, an the nefarious calming chair. COULMIER stares at these  instruments of torture with a mixture of wonder and  foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless we set Charenton on a straight  and narrow course, she'll be shut  down forever by order of the Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelieving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In their eyes, the Marquis is the  surest barometer of your progress  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice rising in  protest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's one among some two hundred  wards--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tried bleeding him with  leeches? The calming chair? Maybe  you should flog him at the stake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  So he'll learn to fear  punishment, rather than pursue virtue  for its own reward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sentimental man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A practical man, sir. Given the  Marquis' unusual tastes, a sound  thrashing on bare flesh may not  qualify as a deterrent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find this amusing, do you? COULMIER rallies passionately on his own behalf:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary. Let me take up this  matter with the Marquis myself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And place my reputation at stake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charenton is my life's work. To have  her wrested from beneath me now-- ROYER-COLLARD pauses. His face softens, and he sighs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've stringent standards, true, but  I've something else the Ministry  failed to take into account; a heart. COULMIER almost collapses with relief and gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank-you, Doctor. I'll effect his  contrition; you have my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER barrels down the hall, fuming. His head is deep the pages of the book; he almost bumps headlong into MADE on her morning rounds. She drops her laundry basket and  flattens herself against the wall:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Abbe? She starts dogging COULMIER down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marquis. He's embarrassed us... (with incredulity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...before Napoleon himself. COULMIER stops. He turns to MADELEINE, disheartened, and  confides the full force of THE MARQUIS' betrayal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been slipping manuscripts to  his publisher. MADELEINE feigns surprise and says in a guilty voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has?
COULMIER nods--tersely--and marches toward THE MARQUIS' d He reaches for the key-chain on his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I place my trust too carelessly,  Madeleine. Unbeknownst to COULMIER, this stings her. He turns the ke in the lock and enters, closing the door behind him. MADELEINE opens the peephole to spy on the scene which  follows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER storms in to find THE MARQUIS in a cloud of whit powder; he's dusting some fresh pages to set the ink. COULMIER slams the book down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a complete...an utter... (his voice falls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...disappointment. THE MARQUIS fingers the book, disapprovingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! It is! The paper's cheap, the  type's too small---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do? Bribe one of the  guards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you implored me to write!  For  curative purposes, to stave off my  madness--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've no right to publish! Behind  my back, without my sanction!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you truly read the book in  question? Or did you run--straightaway--  to the dog-eared pages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to discern its tenor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even a proper novel! It's  nothing but an encyclopedia of  perversions! Frankly, it even fails  as an exercise in craft. The  characters are wooden; the dialogue  is inane. Not to mention the endless  repetition of words like "nipple"  and "pikestaff"--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There I was taxed; it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And such puny scope! Nothing but the  very worst in man's nature!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write of the great, eternal truths  that bind together all mankind! The  whole world over, we eat, we shit,  we fuck, we kill and we die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we also fall in love; we build  cities, we compose symphonies, and  we endure. Why not put that in your  books as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fiction, not a moral treatise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But isn't that the duty of art? To  elevate us above the beast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that was your duty, Abbe,  not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more trick like this, and I'll  be forced to revoke all your  liberties!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that Doctor fellow, isn't it?  He's come to usurp your place here,  hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurting the truth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than your writing's at stake.  The Ministry has threatened us with  closure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't be serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our future lies in the stroke of  your pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed, even  flattered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mightier than the sword indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put yourself in my place. I've your  fellow patients to consider. If  Charenton falls, they've no place to  go. No manner in which to clothe or  feed themselves--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck 'em! They're half-wits and  pinheads. Let 'em die on the streets,  as Nature intended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You among them? This gives THE MARQUIS pause; COULMIER has a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his most passionate  plea yet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ever I showed you a kind hand,  Marquis....If ever I granted you  walking privileges on a Spring day,  or slipped an extra pillow beneath  your door...if ever I shared your  wine, laughed at your vulgarities,  or humored you with argument...then  you will oblige me now.  For your  sake, and for all Charenton. THE MARQUIS--seemingly touched--says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've a touch of the poet, too;  perhaps you should take up the quill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undaunted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have your word? THE MARQUIS catches MADELEINE's reflection in his mirror. In her face, the question: "What on earth are you going t do?" He winks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have no fear, Abbe. He turns back to COULMIER. He has the open, honest eyes o Spaniel, but his words are double-edged:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear; all that Charenton has given  me, I'll repay a hundred-fold. MADELEINE's eyes grow wide with wonder at the prospect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you only mean to dupe me again--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly! You cut me to the core!   What's the point of all your valiant  attempts at rehabilitation if--when  I finally succumb--when at long last,  I pledge myself to righteous conduct-- you regard me with nothing but  suspicion?  Have you no faith in  your own medicine? COULMIER smiles; THE MARQUIS has a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassured)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank-you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE slides the peephole shut. She hears a sound; st at her intensely from the opposite end of the hall, ROYER COLLARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, my.  At Charenton, even the walls  have eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm...don't they?
She scoops up her laundry and barrels on her way. COULMIE leaves the MARQUIS and steps into the hall. He's surprise to see the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to him with reason and  compassion; the tools which serve us  best here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And---?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sworn to obedience. The DOCTOR--ever doubtful--mutters "tsk, tsk, tsk," and t to leave; COULMIER calls after him, insistent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's more than a patient, Doctor;  the Marquis is my friend--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep strange company, Abbe. But  if you truly have matters in hand  here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --then I've friends of my own to  visit. ANGLE ON: THE MARQUIS, watching, ever-watching, from the  hole in his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thunder of hooves. The doctor's coach takes a hair-pi turn at a furious pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD stands beneath the convent's trellis, and p on the door. It opens, revealing the MOTHER SUPERIOR--SIS NOIRCEUIL--a severe-looking nun in a wimple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come for my bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SISTER NOIRCEUIL leads ROYER-COLLARD down the corridor; a heavy set of keys dangles from the belt around her waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd not expected you for some time.   Simone has not yet come of age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've taken a new post at Charenton;  I need the succor only a wife can  provide. They arrive at the room of the convent's ward, SIMONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They interrupt the GIRL in prayer before a porcelain figu of the MADONNA; she rises. With her doe-like eyes and che skin, SIMONE could be the DOCTOR's daughter as readily as his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Dr. Royer-Collard. SIMONE blushes, and casts her eyes downward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd not forget the man to whom I was  promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's come to collect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with alarm:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today? This minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My apologies, Mademoiselle; I'd no  time to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMONE stands in her traveling cape, clutching her MADONN ROYER-COLLARD beside her. A CLUSTER of NUNS has gathered bid SIMONE adieu; among them, the twins SISTER FLAVIE and SISTER ROSE FATIMA. The MOTHER SUPERIOR hands SIMONE a sm valise:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be grateful, child. It's my experience  that most poor girls who are orphaned  never wed; They wind up spinsters,  or worse still... nuns. She takes SIMONE by the chin; her fingers are talons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God that Fortune has spared  you from such a Fate. SISTER NOIRCEUIL bows her head toward ROYER-COLLARD, givi him permission to go. He extends his arm to SIMONE. Hesitantly, she takes it. He guides her toward the waitin carriage. SISTER NOIRCEUIL is grimly pleased. SISTER FLAV and SISTER ROSE FATIMA exchange a look of grave concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Simone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless, Simone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR's carriage lurches down the cobblestone road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD sits stiffly by his new bride; she stares o the window. Looming on the horizon, a towering chateau. SIMONE's eyes grow wide with wonder. TWO MEN stand outsid waiting to greet them, with their own carriage and driver standing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Emperor wishes to ensure your  comfort while at Charenton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DelbenГ© accompanies ROYER-COLLARD and SIMONE across the toward the chateau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider the chateau a gift, provided  you're willing to finance the  necessary repairs.
The DOCTOR assesses his new home up-close; it's fallen in grave disuse. Practically a ruin. DelbenГ© gestures to MO PROUIX, a dimpled young fellow, nattily dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur Prouix is the court's most  promising young architect; he's at  your disposal. MONSIEUR PROUIX offers a friendly grin; the DOCTOR gives the cursory once-over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THREE MEN enter, SIMONE a few paces behind. An opulen space, fallen into desuetude: a marble floor with matchin columns, a domed ceiling, and an expansive staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has possibilities, yes. Simone? SIMONE flinches, surprised the DOCTOR is addressing her s publicly. She says in a voice hushed with awe:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm to live here? ROYER-COLLARD moves toward the stairs; something catches attention. Underfoot, a huge, crimson stain, rimmed in ye The DOCTOR gets down on his haunches and runs a hands ove it. He glances up at DelbenГ©, his face a question mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place hasn't been occupied since  the Terror; it belonged to the Duc  de Blangis, an avowed monarchist.  The Jacobins were most... unforgiving. Lying askance, a moldy old shoe with a cracked heel. DelbenГ© sidles up to ROYER-COLLARD and says confidential

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife was trying to escape; they  caught her on the stair, and set  upon her with bayonets. (shuddering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There but for the grace of God"...eh,  Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't shed tears over the past,  Monsieur DelbenГЁ; I look to the  future. Royer-collard stands and turns to Prouix:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd best quarry fresh marble, don't  you think? PROUIX dutifully makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD coaxes PROUIX aside for a confidential  conversation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're to humor my wife in all things. If she wants Venetian glass, she's  to have it. Italian tile, Dutch  velvet; spare no expense. (lowering his voice  to a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in her bedchamber, see to it  that the door locks from the outside.  And on her windows....an iron grate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bars, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the convent, Simone was spared  the world's temptations. I won't  have her falling prey to them now. ROYER-COLLARD glances over the railing, down below; SIMON stands, overwhelmed, in the enormous atrium. Over her hea the beating of wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a rare bird; I intend to keep  her caged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRAPPED WHITE DOVES flap their feathers madly, trying to through the glass above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louison and Guerin have come to exchange alms for candles from the nuns who make them, SISTER ROSE FATIMA and SISTE FLAVIE. The BOYS load boxes onto the asylum cart. They go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a scandal, truly. Him, pretending  to be a God-fearing man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's not all; he's far too old  to marry, and she's far too young-- LOUISON and GUERIN exchange a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUERIN whispers the tale to a gloriously naked MICHETTE, he makes love to her in the straw. His words are interspe with gasps and moans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I say--the comely little thing--is  barely sixteen-- MICHETTE giggles, and turns to her left. There--surprise- lies LOUISON, pleasuring her from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I say--ah!--she's even younger--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHETTE--in her knickers--now relays the story to MADELE CHARLOTTE glowers, always the odd one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --from a convent, no less; she was  meant to be a nun--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE stands on her overturned basket, whispering to MARQUIS through the peephole. Her lips are luscious rubie in his ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --he's old enough to have fathered  her twice over-- THE MARQUIS' eyes spark with inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, the hypocrite.  It has all the  makings of a farce, hasn't it? Run  straightaway, and tell Franval to  cancel rehearsal... CLOSE UP: A MAGNIFICENT WHITE QUILL PEN. As he blithely hums "Claire de la Lune," THE MARQUIS dips the quill into his ink well; the liquid shoots up the  feather's shaft, turning it a deep purple color. On his PARCHMENT, in calligraphic script, the words "The  Crimes of Love: A Play in Several Lascivious Acts..." THE MARQUIS' little tune rises all the way to symphonic t and we fade up to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight the place looks less like a madhouse and more lik the ComГЁdie Francaise. Mingling on the steps, bejeweled  DOWAGERS and GENTLEMEN in frock-coats. Flanking COULMIER, two GRAND DAMES: MADAME BOUGIVAL and MADEMOISELLE CLAIRWI who's never without her small LAPDOG, even at the theater They bill and coo around the comely priest like magpies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbe de Coulmier! You rascal! Your  comedies have become quite the rage;  I had to claw my way to a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly take credit--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting the  ABBE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so expertly acted! That charming  young man in last week's comedy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd no idea he was an imbecile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has talents, if we look for  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appraising the ABBE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. Yes. I'm sure. COULMIER notices ROYER-COLLARD mounting the steps with SI In her finery, SIMONE looks less like a society bride, an more like a child playing dress-up. COULMIER gives the DO a cordial wave. ROYER-COLLARD nods, curtly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the new Doctor? You must be  thrilled. Such a renowned expert,  right here, at Charenton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evasively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Curtain time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say one thing for him; he has a  beautiful daughter. ANGLE ON: A CARRIAGE, PULLING UP TO THE STEPS. A MYSTERIOUS WOMAN disembarks. She's in her middle years, with a dark bonnet to disguise her identity. She ascends steps to CHARENTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand crumples it; tears it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and we see it's THE MARQUIS. He's in the linen pantry, wh has been jerry-rigged as a BACKSTAGE AREA for the evening Little Theater Performance, which will take place in the  laundry. Poised near him, the Stage Manager for the eveni MADELEINE. They exchange a conspiratorial glance; tonight performance is going to go splendidly! THE MARQUIS survey the LUNATIC CAST spread out before him, readying their ni of glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, gentlemen!  Inside each of  your delicate minds...your distinctive  bodies...ART is waiting to be born.  So let's give the Doctor a performance  I hope he'll remember forever... The CAST gives a rallying cry; THE MARQUIS turns and peer out the tattered velvet curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The catacombs have been converted into a make-shift theat in-the-round. The place has a slightly sinister feel; one Dante's lower circles. A primitive platform stage has bee erected in the spot customarily held by MADAME LECLERC's  vat. The SOCIETY FOLK sit on benches alongside the FEEBLE and DAMNED. THE LUNATIC QUARTET plays its bizarre instruments 18th century curled horns, and home-made strings. A grinn DAUPHIN lights the torches that will illuminate the stage From the AUDIENCE, excited twitters. A grand night for slumming among the loons! A bacchanal! He sees RENEE PELAGIE take her seat, and lower her hood,  craning her neck for a sight of the man she loves. Next, marks ROYER-COLLARD, sitting on a newly-erected dais next his lovely wife SIMONE. COULMIER sits at the DOCTOR's  shoulder, pointing out various notables in the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Bougival; Mademoiselle Clairwil--  and of course--the Marquis' wife--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evincing interest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh indeed? Meanwhile--backstage--FRANVAL nervously taps the MARQUIS the shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon; it's time to  begin. THE MARQUIS drops the curtain, and reminds FRANVAL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dedication, word for word; it's  every bit as crucial as the play  which follows--
FRANVAL nods and takes a deep breath. He bounds onto the  stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice quavering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madames and Messieurs, there's been  a change in tonight's program. ANGLE ON: COULMIER, who stiffens with apprehension. This is an unexpected development.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will not be performing The Happy  Shoemaker. From the AUDIENCE, stirs and murmurs. Perhaps a few  disappointed sighs. From the wings, THE MARQUIS gestures FRANVAL to take a few significant steps forward, toward T DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead, we'd like to premiere a new  play in honor of the newly-appointed  Dr. Royer-Collard and his lovely  bride, married nary a week today-- ANGLE ON: ROYER-COLLARD AND HIS WIFE. The DOCTOR smiles at SIMONE, and touches her hand, fondly polite smattering of applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --a comedy entitled... He dries up. From backstage, THE MARQUIS hisses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crimes of Love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The Crimes of Love, written by  one of Charenton's very own wards! FRANVAL glances back at THE MARQUIS. THE AUDIENCE follows suit. The moment they see SADE, they break into even loud applause than they gave ROYER-COLLARD. The asylum's most  notorious inmate! Right here, before their very eyes! In a show of false modesty, THE MARQUIS blushes, steps ou from behind the curtain, and gives a cursory little bow.
ROYER-COLLARD glances back at COULMIER as if to say "What this?" COULMIER starts fingering his rosary in nervous  anticipation. RENEE PELAGIE just closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LUNATIC dressed as an ANGEL sits high atop one ladder, a DEVIL on another. Together, the TWO start pummeling the stage with artificial snow.  BOUCHON stands in the wings, heaving a giant set of bellows, creating the North Wind. INT. BACKSTAGE. MADELEINE rushes to ready the cast; DAUPHIN is dressed as MOTHER SUPERIOR; he looks markedly like Sister Noirceuil the Panthemont Convent. Behind him, PITOU is the FEMALE  INGENUE; a veritable Simone. He cries out for his bonnet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hat, my hat! MADELEINE affixes his hat, hands PITOU and DAUPHIN each a hobby horse, and pushes them toward the STAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAUPHIN and PITOU ride down the ramp which leads from the linen pantry onto the wooden stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Sister Saint-Fond, whither do we  go?  Passing o'er rivers, canyons  and snow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, Eugenie, for we must not tarry;  I deliver you now to the man you  shall marry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her girlish face alive with pleasure, charmed by the spec before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you have rested, at your leisure--  he'll coach you in the ways of  pleasure. A RIPPLE through the AUDIENCE; tonight's performance is  saucier than usual. As DAUPHIN and PITOU move offstage,  BOUCHON collects their hobby horses.

TWO LUNATICS enter, covered in ornate vines. They form an ARCHWAY. With a drum roll and a thunder-clap, CLEANTE ris from the AUDIENCE--just a few seats away from ROYER-COLLA and hops onstage to assume the role of THE LIBERTINE. GAS of SURPRISE from the crowd. He wears a coat and hat that  match the DOCTOR's. PITOU and DAUPHIN re-enter from the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last she arrives, my hard-won  bride!  Hurry, my child, and scurry  inside.  There you'll find such  treasures await you; Marzipan and  meringue to sate you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such gallantry in men is--sadly--a  rarity; How lucky I am to receive  his charity! The INGENUE ducks through the HUMAN ARCHWAY into the imag CHATEAU. The LIBERTINE passes the MOTHER SUPERIOR a comic large purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, dear Sister, for abetting  me so; Bringing her here to this  secluded Chateau! Little does she  know the terrors in store; when I  tutor her in-- He leans into ROYER-COLLARD for this last bit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...les crimes de l'amour! ANGLE ON: ROYER-COLLARD. He glances all the way past the play, through the AUDIENC seated in the opposite bank. There--looming in the back row against the wall--THE MARQ who grins; the poison arrow has hit his mark. The DOCTOR- ever composed, grins back. An even-handed challenge that  says "I know what you're up to; you're only dooming yours Slyly, THE MARQUIS slips behind a column, disappearing fr view. ROYER-COLLARD whispers to SIMONE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave at once--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's just begun--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as I say. A forlorn SIMONE exits; GAILLON escorts her toward the do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As SIMONE and GAILLON slip toward the exit, THE MARQUIS s waiting for them. He casts a knowing glance at SIMONE, th wisecracks to GAILLON:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving so soon? Oh, but of course!   You've seen it before. GAILLON just glares and hurries SIMONE up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The play continues, full-throttle: BOUCHON pushes a bed  onstage. The INGENUE cowers on the mattress; the LIBERTIN leaps upon her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, my suckling, out of your  clothes! My scepter awaits; how solid  it grows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop, I beg you! Have pity, I say!   You're not my lover; you're a  monstrous rouГЁ! The LIBERTINE yanks up the INGENUE's legs and dives benea her skirts. From beneath the fabric, a host of VULGAR SOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as I say! Stick your legs in the  air! It's true, I'm a pig and you've  truffles down there-- This is all COULMIER can bear; he rises from his seat, in pursuit of THE MARQUIS. He aims for the door, but THE MAR has already disappeared. COULMIER starts scanning the cro hoping to find him in the sea of faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, aware of her husband's presence somewhere behi her. MADAME BOUGIVAL says loudly to MADEMOISELLE CLAIRWIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you suppose is to blame? The  author...or his Muse? RENEE's face falls, stricken. MADAME BOUGIVAL and MADEMOI CLAIRWIL titter behind their fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE LIBERTINE continues to pleasure THE INGENUE with his  mouth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her tone changing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, what's this? Such a  wicked sensation! A feeling somewhere  between shame and elation! Yes!   That's the way; use your tongue like  a wand in much the same manner as  Sister Saint-Fond!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE scurries about, readying the LUNATIC CAST for t Second Act: A FAUX NAPOLEON, A MALE NUN, FRANVAL, DAUPHIN and a LOON DRESSED AS JESUS CHRIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly; the second act! They exit onto the stage. MADELEINE is alone now backstag Or so it seems, until BOUCHON looms up behind her in the  darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: peering through the curtains at the performance. He admir the nape of her neck; her soft shoulders. Meanwhile--onst the play moves apace:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a suspicion the Sister was  Sapphic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd tell you more, but it's simply  too graphic. Suffice it to say, she's  a preference for lasses! Even at  Vespers, she always made passes---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, BOUCHON's hands appears around the base of her  neck; his finger flicker across her cheek. Her face fills with shock, and she disappears behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My darling, Eugenie, dainty morsel!   Get on your back! Let's try it dorsal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was ever a man more risquГЁ? He wants  to take me every way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON yanks MADELEINE behind a curtain, and pushes her- hard--against a stone wall. With a visceral grunt, he gro her beneath her petticoat. She gives a sharp yelp, and re for an iron, still red-hot from the day's work. She presses it--hard--against BOUCHON's cheek. His flesh  sizzles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhggggg....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The obscene pantomime gets wilder by the minute:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER hears BOUCHON's tortured cry, and lurches from t dais, marching directly across the stage. VALCOUR leaps u from his own aisle seat, and follows the PRIEST. The  rollicking play continues onstage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll plunder every lovely pore until  you're weak and cry "no more!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tremble with fear! You're bound to  pound the quivering lips of my Venus  mound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then--to prove your truly mine--  I'll plunder you, darling, from  behind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What of my lips, will you soil them  too? When you've broken every other  taboo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fill every slippery hollow; if  you're obliging, then you'll swallow! COULMIER rips aside the backstage curtain, revealing MADE still out of breath--and BOUCHON, grabbing his face in pa The AUDIENCE--giddy and oblivious--starts to peal with  pleasure; they're certainly getting their money's worth  tonight! VALCOUR seizes BOUCHON roughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him to the infirmary for a  plaster, and an ice bath. That'll  cool him. VALCOUR drags a quivering BOUCHON away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bravely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His stinking breath caused my eyes  to run, that's all. COULMIER kisses her on the forehead. She clutches him in hug, and dissolves into tears.  COULMIER looks up to see MARQUIS standing nearby.  The TWO MEN lock eyes for an  instant; a flicker of jealousy passes between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to take us all down with  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with mock innocence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be absurd; it's only a play. COULMIER glances past THE MARQUIS to see ROYER-COLLARD ri from his seat, and--imperiously--gather his hat and coat. Their eyes meet for an instant; ROYER-COLLARD shoots dagg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the audience now,  expansively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a play!

The AUDIENCE is on its feet now; some cry "Bravo!" Others hurl insults at the stage. Frantic, FRANVAL gestures to t STAGE HANDS to bring the curtain down. EXT. CHARENTON - TERRACE - MINUTES LATER. The DOCTOR flings open the door of his carriage, where SI waits for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was fiction, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brusquely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not inspired by circumstance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It most certainly was not. He boards, slamming the door shut with finality:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to be ashamed, Abbe.   Exploiting those drooling, pathetic  cretins for financial gain--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not our intent--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --a veritable freak show for tourists  and curiosity seekers. Charenton is  a sanatorium; she is not a circus.   The theater is henceforth closed. As  for your avowed friend--playwright  emeritus of the madhouse-- COULMIER swallows; he knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do everything in my power--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off  abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do more. Otherwise, I'll be forced  to report to the Ministry that the  inmates are indeed running the asylum.
The carriage screeches away, leaving Coulmier alone in th night air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER bursts into the MARQUIS's quarters to find him  enjoying a late-night snack of fricandeau, a napkin tied  around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're satisfied; he's shut  down the theater. THE MARQUIS plucks the napkin from around his neck, and t it haughtily onto his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't do that to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can one man possibly be so  selfish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We held a mirror up to the Doctor,  and--apparently--he didn't like what  he saw. COULMIER charges to THE MARQUIS' desk and plucks a hand-f of quills from the ink stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping his fork)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the devil--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you won't be true to your word,  then you've left me no choice. COULMIER grabs quills off the window-sill, the side-board and the secretary. THE MARQUIS realizes COULMIER means  business; he lunges for the ink stand. It spills, sending ink all over his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I kept my promise! I didn't  publish-- COULMIER shoots a glare that says "Oh, please."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps--in time--you'll earn them  back through good behavior--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't--! You mustn't--! I've all  the demons of hell in my head; my  only salvation is to vent them on  paper--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try reading, for a change. The writer  who produces more than he reads? The  sure mark of an amateur. He snares a Bible off the shelf, tossing it to THE MARQUI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start with the Bible; it's cheerier,  and more artfully written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spitting on its cover)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That monstrous God of yours? He strung  up his very own son like a side of  veal; I shudder to think what He'd  do to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what sacrilege is, don't  you?  The last refuge of the failed  provocateur. COULMIER yanks open the desk drawer. In it, bottles of in He starts to fill his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (truly frightened now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll die of loneliness! I've no  company but the characters I create--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whores and pederasts? You're better  off without them. The MARQUIS abruptly switches gears; he has a new idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a proposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine. She's besotted with me;  she'd do anything I ask. She could  pay you a midnight visit--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who you insult more;  her or me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Part the gates of heaven," as it  were--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're tense, darling. You could use  a long, slow screw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Marquis.

dialogues.speaker: THEN BUGGER ME
dialogues.text: COULMIER exits, locking the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: SENSE OF MY CONDITION
dialogues.text: My writing is involuntary, like the  beating of my heart! My constant  erection! I can't help it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside his cell, the MARQUIS pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGOT
dialogues.text: COULMIER pauses. He hears the sliding of the peep-hole in the door.  He turns back to see the MARQUIS staring at hi through the tiny slit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where there's a will, there's a way.   And a maniac is matchless for  invention.
The peephole slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALCOUR admits the MYSTERIOUS WOMAN from the theater, THE MARQUIS' WIFE, RENEE PELAGIE. The MARQUIS stares out his  cell window without acknowledging her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done just as you bade me; I've  paid a visit to the woodcarver. He  laughed and called me a whore, but  took my money just the same. She sets a satchel down on his desk, and unwraps it. Inside, two wooden prods, each about nine inches long. On is ebony; the other rosewood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what brings you more  pleasure; the objects themselves, or  the humiliation I endure procuring  them on your behalf. Next, she proffers a small box tied with a gold bow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And--last but not least--I've brought  you aniseed drops and some chocolate  pastilles. This gets his attention; he turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you now, Madame? His face softens, and he says with a suggestive lilt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're filled with cream, yes? You  know I shan't touch them, unless  they're positively bursting--erupting--  with cream. RENEE PELAGIE blushes happily, delighted that she's pleas him. THE MARQUIS crosses to her; en route, he notices VALCOUR, spying through the peephole. He snaps it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else have you brought that I  might nibble upon? He presses her against the wall, cupping her breast, and  kissing the tip of her nose. She offers faint protest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Donatien...you mustn't.. He licks the rim of her ear as he whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? Tell me.  What other treats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helpless with giggles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....shame on you, truly... Suddenly--savagely--he slaps her; she reels, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fuck's sake, woman! BONBONS? I'm  to sit here, gorging myself on useless  trifles, sucking down your little  sweetmeats, when what I truly need--  what I truly require--are a few quill  pens? Perhaps a pot of ink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I beg you--- He pulls the drawers from his desk, and hurls them to the ground; they splinter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see? I've been raped! Far  more egregiously than any of my  wretched characters--- RENEE PELAGIE breaks away from him, and says in a voice  cracked with emotion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I to know, my darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I to tell you? By writing a  letter? WITH WHAT, MY ASININE BRIDE? RENEE PELAGIE backs herself into a corner, a safe distanc from her husband, and implores:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, Donatien...as your  wife...your only ally...you must  stop making such a monstrous spectacle  of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've come to lecture me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To flaunt your deviance in public?   Upon a stage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've put you up to this, haven't  they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to court the Doctor's favor,  not his contempt. THE MARQUIS tears open the box of candy, and pops one int his mouth. He chews:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to carve my name into his  backside, and fill the wounds with  salt-- RENEE PELAGIE's eyes well; she dabs them with a handkerch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here--safe--surrounded by  brick and mortar; but my prison is  far crueler. It has no walls. She starts speaking in a mad rush, tripping over her own  words, frantic to spill it all out before he cuts her off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere I go, they point and  whisper! At the opera, they hiss at  me when I take my box. When I went  to church...the priest refused to  even hear my confession; he said I  was already damned! Why must I suffer  for your sins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the way of all martyrs, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me back my anonymity, that's  all I ask! Let me be invisible again! THE MARQUIS explodes now, his eyes spinning with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me; have you done anything to  secure my release? NO!  Have you  petitioned the court? NEVER! Sought  audience with the Emperor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He refuses to be seen in my company!   He blanches at the mention of your  name--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a convenience, isn't it, having  your husband locked away!  You no  longer have to hold your tongue, or  hoist your skirts!  Or crack your  mouth, so I can put it to its one  pleasurable use!  YOU'RE NOT MY WIFE,

dialogues.speaker: AREN'T YOU
dialogues.text: RENEE PELAGIE starts to sob, convulsively. VALCOUR--heari the commotion--re-enters the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the name a' God--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this cow away; I can't look at  her. VALCOUR escorts a fragile RENEE PELAGIE from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'll find a place for her  in the West Wing, eh? AMONG THE

dialogues.speaker: HYSTERICS
dialogues.text: As they lumber out, THE MARQUIS bellows after them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the rear of her carriage, RENEE PELAGIE. She's dried h tears, and now bears a look of fierce resolve: a woman im with a mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRAFTSMEN buzz about the place like flies, carrying gilde mirrors, uncrating sculpture, fitting wall sconces, etc. GAILLON stands by at the door. ROYER-COLLARD AND MONSIEUR PROUIX are at one end of the room, in rapt consultation. Swatches, marble samples, and blueprints litter their tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a woman of humble origin, your  wife certainly has refined tastes!   When I suggest granite for the foyer,  she's quick to counter with Peruvian  marble. Peruvian marble! It costs a  fortune to import! SIMONE wafts past on the balcony above; she glances down them, smiles.  ROYER-COLLARD assumes the smile is meant f him; he offers a tiny wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever her heart desires, Monsieur  Prouix. MONSIEUR PROUIX assumes the smile is his; he offer his ow toothsome grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like nothing better, sir, than  to grant her every wish. (sotto voce, to the  DOCTOR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But on the modest sum you've accorded  me--I'm an architect, not a magician-- RENEE PELAGIE brushes past GAILLON with gale force:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must see the Doctor at once. It's  a matter of dire urgency... ROYER-COLLARD spies her instantly; their eyes lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is customary to write first, and  request an appointment--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desperation has driven me past  etiquette, all the way to frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My schedule is not subject to the  whims of lunatics. RENEE PELAGIE removes her hat, indicating her intention t stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg to differ, Doctor. You work in  a madhouse. Your every waking moment  is governed by the insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray you: be succinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're new to Charenton, yes? Perhaps  you're not yet familiar with my  husband, and his unusual case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Madame, all  France is familiar with your husband. (to MONSIEUR PROUIX)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant us a moment alone, won't you,  Monsieur Prouix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happily, sir. Your servant, sir. He gestures for the CRAFTSMEN to follow him out. The room a veritable hive of activity--is now silent. DR. ROYER-CO offers RENEE PELAGIE a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, please. RENEE sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you've come to plead for  clemency on your husband's behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you do, do you? It is my dearest  hope, Doctor, that he remain entombed  forever, and that when at last he  perishes in the dank bowels of your  institution, he be left as carrion  for the rodents and the worms. The DOCTOR's somewhat taken aback:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stand corrected, Madame. Now that she's alone in the DOCTOR's company, the full fo of RENEE PELAGIE's despair issues forth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't cure him--truly cure  him-- then--at least--I beg you-- harness the beast that rages in his  soul. The wheels in ROYER-COLLARD'S brain begin to turn; he idl fingers a swatch of fabric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so easily done, Madame. He rises, circling RENEE PELAGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're aware, are you not, that it  costs a great deal to house your  husband at Charenton...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay his stipend every month, far  more dutifully than I should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That barely covers the cost of his  room. There's nary a penny left over  for appropriate treatments. Opiates  to quell his temper. Restraints to  chasten him when he misbehaves. RENEE PELAGIE can sense the direction of the conversation she blushes, and stares at her hands in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if you were to buttress your  entreaties with the means to oblige  them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a wealthy woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've a pension, haven't you,  from the sale of his books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tainted money, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful thought, Marquise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What thought is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ill-gotten funds, borne of his  degeneracy, might now effect his  salvation. RENEE ponders the thought; it has a certain righteous  symmetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're truly determined to step  out of the shadow of your husband's  celebrity--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --words alone are insufficient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beyond perversity. That honor  should carry a price tag... The DOCTOR rises and crosses to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine; old friends once again  deigning to kiss your hand. (kissing her hand,  seductively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Why, Marquise. Enchanted to see  you.  Welcome back from your long,  dark descent into the abyss of  infamy."
RENEE's flustered; it's been a long time, and the DOCTOR  does have his charms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't toy with me, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now is the time to secure your  epitaph: The benevolent Marquise,  Charenton's most revered  philanthropist...or Satan's Bride. A torturous moment of indecision for RENEE PELAGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR and RENEE PELAGIE step into the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest assured that your generosity  speeds your husband ever faster toward  a cure. MONSIEUR PROUIX bolts up from the front steps of the CHAT ROYER-COLLARD whispers through his teeth:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Peruvian marble; without question. MONSIEUR PROUIX stares after the DOCTOR, baffled. The DOC escorts RENEE PELAGIE into her carriage. She gazes soulfu into his eyes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am eternally in your debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I in yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor... Can I impart to you his  cruelest trick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once...long ago...in the folly of  youth...he made me love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MARQUIS lies against his pillow, his eyes flickering  malevolently in the candlelight. He hears the tinkling of dinner china outside his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE carries a dinner tray for THE MARQUIS. She reac his cell. He slides open his peep-hole. His voice has the desperate rasp of a man in withdrawal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine, my sweet...can you smuggle  a paper and quill to me? MADELEINE shoves the tray under his door; she glances dow the hall to see VALCOUR stationed there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't dare. The Doctor's got his  eye on you, sharper than ever now. She gives him an apologetic look, and ambles on her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MARQUIS plops his tray down on his desk. Wine from th carafe sloshes out; a few drops land on his napkin. He st at the pattern of the burgundy drops against the white of the linen. He traces a finger along the splotch. His face lights up; an idea. He grabs the carafe in one h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the room. In front of him, his bed. The she are stretched against it immaculately: not so much as a  wrinkle. Inch after inch of white; a beautiful blank page

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MARQUIS rips into the meat with his hands; he ferrets out a bone. Next, he takes a tiny carving knife, and whit away at it, sharpening its point and hollowing its marrow Voila. A make-shift quill. He dips it into the carafe.  N he tries a few strokes on the pillow-case over his desk. makes a clean, bold line. His eyes fill with grateful tea and he hugs himself in the night air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One lamp burns in the darkness in the MARQUIS' chamber; t sound of a quill scraping across linen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dr. Montalivet was--politely put--a  diminutive man. When flaccid, his  member was little more than a bobbin,  and--when enflamed--it towered a  mere four inches. To compensate, he  strove to impress his lady love with  a host of other endowments; fine- wine, fresh game, and a house as  large as his other fortunes were  small..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enormous table separates ROYER-COLLARD from SIMONE. Even the dining room is in the midst of renovation; half walls are covered in silk damask; the other half are bare SIMONE reads from a thin book. ROYER-COLLARD has had more than his share from the carafe of wine; he's feeling  "expansive" tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've ceiling beams en route from  Provence, and--next week--a muralist  arrives from Paris, to paint a trompe- l'oeil in the ballroom. SIMONE doesn't look up from her reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't that please you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconvincingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd prefer to have our brandy in the  salon. There we can sit...side-by- side...before the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather read, thank-you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You prefer a book to your husband's  company? SIMONE glances down at her hands, trembling in her lap. S can't bring herself to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no wonder; I'm only flesh and  blood. That's no match--is it?--for  the printed page. He stands, sullen, and tosses his napkin onto his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, then. I hope you enjoy  your solitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The canopy around the bed is closed. Behind it, a comely  silhouette; SIMONE is awake, reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed only in a night-shift, SIMONE holds a book in one hand and a candle in the other. She hears footsteps; the  door opens. SIMONE blows out her candle. Through the curt she sees the looming shadow of her husband, carrying a ta of his own. ROYER-COLLARD parts the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize if I took a severe tone. He plucks the book from her hands, and regards its title a moment: A Lady's Garden of Verse. He smiles, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be blamed for your naivetГЁ,  not when it's chief among your charms. He climbs into bed next to her; she rolls on her side, fa away from him. He presses himself hard against her back a whispers hoarsely in her ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps the Sisters failed to instruct  you in the ways of marriage; the  nightly duty of a wife to her husband. He takes the hem of her night-shift in hand, and with a  wrenching rrrriiiippp starts to tear it up the rear. SIMONE--terrified at what's to come--seeks solace from th room's only comfort: the porcelain MADONNA from the Panth Convent sitting on her nightstand. The VIRGIN exudes a ho light that illuminates SIMONE, even as she's violated by husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight falls in a crisscross pattern through the grate the MARQUIS' window. He snores, asleep at his desk. A KNO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your linens! His eyes snap open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE pounds again, glancing nervously at the ever-pr VALCOUR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now or never! The trap opens, and sheets pour out. MADELEINE gathers th and notices something odd. Her face lights up with amazem She unfurls the top sheet. It's covered in script. She st it down in her basket, and scurries past VALCOUR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE sits by the fire. She unfolds THE MARQUIS' beds with loving care; like his pillowcase, its covered in wor She starts to transcribe it.  MADAME LECLERC sits near-by her rocking chair, knitting, her hands nimble in spite of her blindness.  She hears the "scratch, scratch" of a qui tip across parchment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you won't read it to your own  Mama, then perhaps you ought not to  be reading it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your cup of tea, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, darling, give it a read. She clears her throat, and begins to read:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Monsieur Bouloir was a man whose  erotic tastes might discreetly be  described as 'post-mortem.'" MADAME LECLERC can't help it; she smiles a naughty smile. Emboldened, MADELEINE starts to read in proud, clear tone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A habituГЁ of cemeteries, his proudest  conquest was a maid six decades his  senior, deceased a dozen years."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's terrible!  It's too, too  terrible! (a pause, and then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The vigor with which he made love  caused her bones to dislodge. Still,  he granted her the highest compliment  he accorded any woman..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tenterhooks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Well worth the dig!" MOTHER and DAUGHTER shriek with delight and revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He--too--issues a low giggle, amused by the story, arouse by its reader...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE slips the manuscript to the HORSEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked my name once; it's  Madeleine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet, then? Like the pastry? He grins and cracks the reins; his horse canters away. MADELEINE calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you a name yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride away with me someday, and perhaps  I'll tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADAME LECLERC sinks the scribbled sheets into a steaming vat of boiling water. She shoves it down with a large sti stick. The water turns red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE and MICHETTE are pulling the sodden sheets from their baskets in order to hang them. They exchange a look something's askance. The sheets have an odd crimson hue. "Off-color" indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam rises thick as soup from the laundry vats. With a  flourish, ROYER-COLLARD unrolls a ruddy bedsheet for  MADELEINE's inspection. COULMIER stands by. MADAME LECLER creaks back and forth in her chair, anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother may be blind as a bat,  but you've a keen pair of eyes,  haven't you? MADELEINE flares defensively on her mother's behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama's blind on account of the lye  in the laundry kettles; soaking sheets  for lunatics cost the poor woman her  sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could cost her far more---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intervening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get more from her with kindness  than you will with force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could cause a tincture like  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only a laundress; not a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now's not the time to be cheeky,  Maddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps your kettles are stained  with rust. Maybe the lye's turned  rancid. Or maybe...just maybe... He plucks a candle from the wall sconce, and holds it beh the sheet; bleeding through the fabric, traces of cursive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...these sheets once belonged to our  friend, The Marquis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've over two hundred beds. They  could've been anybody's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a fine thread-count? Decorated  in his very own script? ROYER-COLLARD turns to COULMIER and says decisively:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's lying. It shows in her face. COULMIER looks at MADELEINE, imploringly. Now is the time tell the truth. But MADELEINE--though her cheeks are blus with guilt--doesn't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacked in the hallway, THE MARQUIS' furnishings; his cha longue, his wardrobe, his bed. Paintings tilted against t wall; sculptures sitting upside down. And.trundling from cell, GUARDS. ONE carries drawers, newly pulled from ches ANOTHER, a candelabra and a crate of nicknacks. From insi we hear THE MARQUIS crying in protest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Don't you dare! Touch that, and  I'll have your testicles on toast!   MORONS! THIEVES! Help! That's  fifteenth century, you goon! PUT

dialogues.speaker: THOSE IVORIES DOWN--
dialogues.text: LOUISON comes teetering forth with a wheelbarrow, stacked high with books.  And--marching down the hall in supervis mode--COULMIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost done, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember--anything--ANYTHING he might  fashion as a quill. His entire room,  stripped bare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER bursts in; THE MARQUIS rails. COULMIER goes righ to work, casing the bedroom, orchestrating the further re of items from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So! The Doctor cracks the whip, and  you dance! He gestures toward the barren space in the center of the  room, incredulous:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My bed, gone! Am I to freeze to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing to GUERIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my chaise--am I being denied the  privilege of sitting--of plopping  down my ass--- GUERIN gathers the rug, and heads for the door. LOUISON  returns with the wheelbarrow, now empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a Turkish weave, you numbskull;  it costs more than you'll earn in  your lifetime-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valcour. His chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALCOUR and LOUISON cart out the  MARQUIS' arm-chair, orange peels and  all. COULMIER starts emptying books  from the shelves into the wheelbarrow;  pages scatter and bindings break.  The MARQUIS decides to "pitch in"  with rueful glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! Take it! Take it all! Here-- He tosses a candlestick into the wheelbarrow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, it's slippery, you've no  idea where it's been. A box of Kama  Sutra powder, ready to dust whomever  you please... He plucks a small statue of the Virgin Mary from his shel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we mustn't forget Mary, sweet  Mary, the Jewish Whore; God's little  harlot! He hurls it into the wheelbarrow, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgin birth--ha! An entire religion,  built on an oxymoron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orvolle. His wine. (back to THE MARQUIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, nothing but water at  every meal--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --water!---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and your meat shall be de-boned. The MARQUIS attempts to pirate away a pair of wine bottle but VALCOUR intercepts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because your writing continues,  unchecked. COULMIER starts plucking THE MARQUIS' pornographic etchin off the wall. Panicked now, THE MARQUIS rails:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its horrors, perhaps!  Its darkest  nightmares! And to what end? Nothing  but your own morbid gratification--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morbid gratification? NO! I write  what I've seen; the endless procession  to the chopping block. We're all  lined up at the guillotine, waiting  for the crunch of the blade. Rivers  of blood are flowing beneath our  feet, Abbe. THE MARQUIS turns back to COULMIER with the eyes of a man who has seen too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been to hell, young man. You've  only read about it. COULMIER realizes--for the first time--the full depth of MARQUIS's misanthropy. There's no point in arguing furthe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Marquis. Truly. He turns and heads into the corridor. THE MARQUIS follows him out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MARQUIS pulls him up short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Priest. These chastity vows  of yours. How strict are they? COULMIER pauses, stiffening. THE MARQUIS turns unctious:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose you only put it in her mouth--- Suddenly, COULMIER lunges at the MARQUIS, pinning him to wall by his neck. VALCOUR, ORVOLLE, GUERIN and LOUISON al freeze, ready to pounce. PITOU and DAUPHIN have emerged f their cells, curious about the clammer. CLEANTE watches f his peephole. THE MARQUIS gives a sly grin; he's hit a nerve. COULMIER  lets THE MARQUIS go with a shove.  His face stone, he hea back down the long hall.

dialogues.speaker: PIOUS LITTLE WORM--
dialogues.text: ORVOLLE and VALCOUR grab him by each arm; he glares at  COULMIER; his eyes are wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In conditions of adversity, the artist  flourishes. They drag him back to his cell and slam the door.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. THE MARQUIS' REFLECTION
dialogues.text: Suddenly, it shatters, splintering like ice. THE MARQUIS slammed his own fist into a lone mirror. He picks up a sh of glass and braces himself. With a grimace, he slashes h finger. He winces, a sound lodged somewhere between pleas and pain.  Next, he holds his finger over the ink well, a squeezes. Blood starts to dribble--one drop at a time--in the tiny bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall at the asylum; the topiary has shed its leaves; tang branches claw at the air like giant, hungry birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE collects bedding on her routine run. She steps  over VALCOUR, who's snoring loudly outside THE MARQUIS' d The trap opens, and THE MARQUIS grabs her by the ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking back sobs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst. Madeleine. I beg you... MADELEINE looks down. On all ten of THE MARQUIS' fingerti bandages torn from cloth and soaked with bloodstains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have they done to you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
