dialogues.text: Tortures so arcane, so medieval,  even I haven't the words to describe  them. If you've an ounce of pity in  your heart, you'll throw caution  aside, and unlock my door... MADELEINE glances at VALCOUR, who shifts in his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God help me; I don't dare. THE MARQUIS abruptly shifts his tone; no tears now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a dunce, child. I've a  surprise for you. Now open the  frigging door. MADELEINE screws up her courage, and slips the key in the lock. She twists the handle, leaving the door ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MARQUIS stands before MADELEINE, looking absolutely  resplendent, in a suit covered in words, all written in h own blood. Quite a feat indeed. She gasps; her eyes fill  with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My newest book begins at my right  cuff, continues across my back, and  completes itself at the base of my  left shoe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it! He turns in a slow circle, like a fashion model on parade A few tell-tale words are visible: "pikestaff," perhaps. Maybe "nipple." MADELEINE can't help it; she blurts a gig THE MARQUIS joins her. Soon, they're both helpless with  laughter. Suddenly, THE MARQUIS remembers VALCOUR, just  outside the door. He presses a finger to his lips; MADELE goes silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your leave, quickly, so you  won't be blamed for my misbehavior. Suddenly--impulsively--she kisses him, hard, upon the lip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be a proper writer without  a touch of madness, can you? She slips out. THE MARQUIS stands for a moment, stunned b her unexpected display of feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE almost runs into CHARLOTTE, whose been spying o her in the hall. CHARLOTTE scowls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic with the Devil, Maddy, and  you'll pay the Devil's price. Just then, THE MARQUIS slips from his cell and scurries p a vision in his hand-tailored novel. CHARLOTTE's eyes bul with astonishment. MADELEINE grins. With a tremor in her  voice, CHARLOTTE cries out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valcour! Valcour! MADELEINE breaks into a run, disappearing around the corn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FACES OF THE LUNATICS, AGAPE WITH WONDER. One mouths few words, aloud. Another stomps his feet with reckless  enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Dancing down the center of the longest table, THE MARQUIS He skips over loaves of bread, and overturned goblets. PITOU is reading his waistcoat; BOUCHON paws at his leggi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feast your eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two chapters, one for each cheek! MY

dialogues.speaker: WRITING LIVES
dialogues.text: Giddy from the loss of blood, THE MARQUIS collapses on th table. THE LUNATICS pounce upon him to read every word; h laughs with victorious delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sister Mary Quesnet had the most  dextrous vulva in all France--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "---so he set about removing her  teeth--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She'd never been with another woman,  never mind her own mother--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "--twin orbs of delight--with her  puckered mouth, she swallowed him  whole-"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She wore her ass proudly---" ANGLE ON: the dining hall doors, banging open ROYER-COLLARD enters, VALCOUR, GAILLON and CHARLOTTE--the stool pigeon--flank him on either side; he spies the MARQ instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to VALCOUR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this beast back to his cage. All the PATIENTS stare dumbly at the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me. You've come to read  my trousers. On ROYER-COLLARD's face, the utmost contempt; the MARQUIS grins, ear-to-ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't keep me in suspense. What'll  it be? Fifty lashes? A night on the  rack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't sully my hands with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor should you. That's the first  rule of politics, isn't it? (a sly insinuation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who orders the execution  never drops the blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP: COULMIER, whose face bears all the frustration a new parent, saddled with an incorrigible child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky it falls to me to punish  you.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: COULMIER paces, to and fro. The MARQUIS, still dressed in his "novel," sits on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were up to the Doctor, you'd  be flayed alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man after my own heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in God's name am I to do with  you?  The more I forbid, the more  you're provoked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could be convinced to abandon my  writing, quite voluntarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth would that require?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night spent with the partner of my  choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to pimp Madeleine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't talking about Madeleine. The MARQUIS blows a kiss in COULMIER's direction; COULMIE turns a fiery red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulmier, you animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you must, my pumpkin! Sex  without flirtation is merely rape!

dialogues.speaker: NOW STRIP.
dialogues.text: The MARQUIS begins to undress, hurriedly. First his tailc then his waistcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shoes; they're naught but  punctuation. COULMIER just glares. THE MARQUIS kicks them off, too. He twists the amber ring off his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My jewels, family or otherwise? Once again, COULMIER refuses to be roped into THE MARQUIS little game.  THE MARQUIS seizes the ring in his teeth, a proffers COULMIER a gritted, ugly smile.  COULMIER plucks the ring out of his maw. THE MARQUIS now stands in nothin but his stockings and trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your breeches as well. THE MARQUIS unhooks the first button on his breeches, the waits, expectantly, for COULMIER to do the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You started this little game; you  finish it. Or haven't you the courage? COULMIER falters; he wasn't expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorting derisively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought not. He lets his trousers drop. In the dim shadows, the MARQUI is naked now, except for his hair. He sidles up, close, t COULMIER, his breath in the priest's ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a potent aphrodisiac, isn't it?   Power over another man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wig. Remove your wig.
The MARQUIS slides off his wig, and places it over his  privates, swinging it, like the tail of a horse. COULMIER reaches out and grabs it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll no longer spread your insidious  gospel, where art's magnitude is the  breadth of its depravity! FROM NOW

dialogues.speaker: IGNOMINIOUS NAME
dialogues.text: So much anger seethes between them, it's electric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are your convictions so fragile that  mine cannot stand in opposition to  them? Is your God so flimsy? So weak?   For shame! The thinnest trace of a smile dances on COULMIER's lips;  he's won this round, and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't flatter yourself, Marquis. You're not the Anti-Christ.  You're  nothing but a malcontent who knows  how to spell. With that, COULMIER exits with THE MARQUIS' clothing in h arms. THE MARQUIS is left alone, naked and pathetic, in a empty cell. INT. CORRIDOR - MEANWHILE. ROYER-COLLARD storms down the hall toward MADELEINE's  quarters, with VALCOUR, GAILLON and CHARLOTTE on his heel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw her with my own eyes.  She put  the key in the latch, just as proud  as you please--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine's head, framed against the sky Reminiscent of the GUILLOTINE VICTIM in the film's openin sequence. A SECOND HEAD looms into frame. Only--instead o belonging to an EXECUTIONER--this one belongs to VALCOUR.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: VALCOUR ties MADELEINE's wrists to the posts of the well the center of the yard. With scissors, he slowly cuts the
laces up the back of her corset, exposing her back. Next, raises a steel-tipped martinet, poised to whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She singles out faces: ROYER-COLLARD, who watches imperio from a window above, GAILLON at his side. CHARLOTTE, who  watches the proceedings with smug satisfaction. MADAME  LECLERC, whose foggy eyes are filled with tears. MICHETTE LOUISON, GUERIN and ORVOLLE, all faces ripe with sympathy And--separated by a fence--the LUNATICS--FRANVAL, PITOU,  CLEANTE, and DAUPHIN among them. BOUCHON, a hideous scar on his cheek from the iron, all b drools in anticipation. VALCOUR looks to ROYER-COLLARD for permission to strike;  coolly ROYER-COLLARD grants it. MADELEINE flinches in  anticipation of the blow. It comes down, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MADELEINE shudders in pain, the DOCTOR can't help hims he quivers--ever so slightly--with pleasure. An angry wel appears on MADELEINE's skin. Then another. She chokes back tears, enduring her punishment with digni COULMIER bursts forth from the CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: FREE HER. NOW.
dialogues.text: VALCOUR stops short; he turns to ROYER-COLLARD. THE DOCTO stands, menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll do no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a weak man who tests his mettle  on the backs of children--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This child let loose the beast from  its cage--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine's not wicked. It's the  Marquis who's corrupted her. That's  not her fault; it's mine. COULMIER turns to VALCOUR, and whispers urgently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dagger. Give me your dagger. VALCOUR looks to the DOCTOR; which superior should he hon

dialogues.speaker: LEAVE HER DULY STRUNG.
dialogues.text: COULMIER reaches out and slides the dagger from VALCOUR's belt. He slices through the rope that binds MADELEINE; sh grabs him for support, and whispers urgently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong to free him, but so are  you--for taking all his treasures-- his quills and his ink--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, or we're both done for. COULMIER turns back to ROYER-COLLARD and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only blood will appease you, then  shed mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd suffer in her stead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbe, no-- COULMIER proffers both fists to VALCOUR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Bind them. Bind them. Reluctantly, VALCOUR ties Coulmier's hands together. Next he hikes them over the whipping post. He loosens COULMIER vestments, stripping them to the waist. Next, he raises h martinet and turns to ROYER-COLLARD for permission to str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary. A sigh of relief from the CROWD. As VALCOUR frees him,  COULMIER rubs his wrists. ROYER-COLLARD stares at him wit steel eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to martyr yourself, Abbe,  do it for God. Not a chambermaid.  Now put your clothes back on.
COULMIER--chastened--turns a blazing red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE sits on the examining table, her bodice pulled  down around her waist.  A severe-looking NUN prepares sal for the lashes on her back. COULMIER sits behind a small  folding screen--for modesty--and talks to MADELEINE; it t considerable strength of will to keep from peeking at her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had I known your taste in novels, I  never would've taught you to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that; reading's my  salvation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why must you indulge in his  pornography?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hard day's wages, slaving  away for madmen. What I've seen in  life, it takes a lot to hold my  interest. The NUN presses a sponge against a particularly nasty gas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why heap such ghastly fantasies  atop an already ghastly existence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put myself in his stories. I play  the parts. Each strumpet, each  murderess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not act the role of heroines  instead? Queen Esther from the Bible,  or St. Joan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I wasn't such a bad woman on the  page, Abbe, I'll hazard I couldn't  be such a good woman in life. The NUN has finished dressing her wounds; MADELEINE stand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the partition in the screen COULMIER catches a gl of MADELEINE's body: the upturn of her breasts, the soft  slope of her back. He turns away, ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no place for a child like  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD sits at a table, ledger before him, MONSIEU PROUIX on one side, GAILLON on the other. Lining up for  payment, various CRAFTSMEN: a BRICKLAYER, perhaps, A  CARPENTER, A GARDENER. The DOCTOR hands a small sheath of bills to a particularly large STONE-MASON. When the STONE MASON steps out of the frame, the DOCTOR is confronted by surprising sight: an incensed RENEE PELAGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God, Marquise--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the brink of bankruptcy; my  husband's resources are all but  exhausted. And to what end, I ask  you? ROYER-COLLARD glances behind her; more MEN await payment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is neither the time nor the  place--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only you'd remained true to our  contract! Opiates, for his nerves!   Restraints! The man warrants a bed  of nails--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can say, with the utmost sincerity,  that every franc you've given me has  been put to sterling use. RENEE PELAGIE glances about the room, taking inventory of its contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That much is painfully clear. He stands and announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentleman, if you'll excuse us...only  a moment...thank you, thank you... Amidst grumbles, GAILLON clears the room, closing the doo behind him. MONSIEUR PROUIX hovers behind it, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've no right to assault me in  this fashion; I'll call for my  footman.  I'll have you removed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I a cursed woman, Doctor? Must I  be betrayed by every man I meet-- SIMONE appears on the balcony above. She's overheard the  commotion, and senses something is amiss. The DOCTOR shif his gaze, staring up at her; RENEE PELAGIE notices that t DOCTOR's attention has been diverted, and whirls around t face SIMONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! This must be the little Madame. SIMONE offers a faint, uncertain smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must confess, I envy you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Envy me? But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband's name brings you honor,  doesn't it? You can walk down the  street without insult; without falling  debris. RENEE PELAGIE's brow darkens with sinister pleasure; she  gestures at the riches in the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But suppose the whole world knew  that all this splendor was the result  of fraudulence? Of extortion? SIMONE stares at her husband, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why has she come here?
RENEE PELAGIE continues to address SIMONE, even as she fi her stare upon the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Public scorn carries a terrible sting.   Trust me. I'm a woman who knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's libelous; you wouldn't dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why not? My fortune, siphoned  away.  My reputation, past repair.  I've nothing left to lose. (her eyes narrowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence my husband, or you'll come  to know an infamy to rival his own. RENEE PELAGIE glances at SIMONE, who glances at her husba who glowers back at RENEE PELAGIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG WOMAN navigates the winding streets. In her elega attire--notably the broad-brimmed hat which conceals her  face--she's clearly out of place in this neighborhood. VENDORS in cramped shanties and make-shift stalls cry out THE WOMAN as she passes. Their VOICES fade in and out of another, like a demented chorus. The FIRST is a hairy,  toothless bag o' bones:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst...Mademoiselle....I've only a  few doses of Spanish fly left... The WOMAN continues on her way, without glancing back. He cape billows behind her. The SECOND VENDOR is a scurvy li jackal indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat-o'-nine-tails here, guaranteed  to raise a welt... The THIRD--a feisty little DWARF--has nothing but herself sell. She coos to the WOMAN:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curious, aren't you? If I can pleasure  me-self, I can pleasure you, too... At the end of the line, the WOMAN reaches the most decrep booth of all. She reaches to ring the tiny bell, and the  knocker falls off in her hand. She pounds on the door wit
her fist instead. From WITHIN, scurrying sounds. The DOOR cracks open a sliver, and an EYE peers out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an insinuating  lilt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PAWNBOKER's a sinister fellow with shifty eyes. His  CUSTOMER is none other than SIMONE, the DOCTOR's wife. Sh glances about to ensure that the coast is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covertly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in search of a book; perhaps you  know it. She slips the PAWNBROKER a scrap of paper; he reads it, t regards her warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only got copy left; rescued it  me-self from the bonfire. SIMONE bats her eyes, hopefully. The PAWNBROKER sighs, re under the counter, and pulls up a STRONG BOX, with a chai yoking it to the floor. The PAWNBROKER reaches high on a  shelf for the hidden key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hurry. My husband locks the  door at dusk. THE PAWNBROKER opens the lock, and lifts the lid; in the  box, Justine. SIMONE scrounges in her purse for the requi francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet little thing like you shouldn't  be reading such filth anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grew up in a convent, sir.   Everything I know in the world, I  owe to books. And the book itself almost seems to speak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To the young maidens of the world..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIMONE is at her vanity, with a letter-opener and a glue  pot. Gently, she loosens the cover off A Lady's Garden of Verse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wrest yourselves free from the  tyranny of virtue, and taste without  shame the pleasures of the flesh..." She slathers it with glue, and starts affixing it to her  newly-purchased copy of the Marquis de Sade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Male power lies in the clench of a  fist. But a woman's power lies  elsewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD snoozes in his nightcap. SIMONE has her hea deep in a book: A Lady's Garden of Verse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... in the velvet cavity betwixt  her thighs..." The light from her oil lamp irritates THE DOCTOR; he open one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late, Simone, darling. Put your  poems aside. SIMONE just licks her forefinger, and turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROUIX holds a swatch against the dining room wall for  SIMONE's approval: the Napoleonic crest, in royal blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or--if you prefer--a Florentine  tapestry? SIMONE glances at ROYER-COLLARD, who's preoccupied with t FOREMAN in the atrium. She turns to PROUIX and smiles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a literary man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? From the folds of her skirt, SIMONE pulls her book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I so admire men with an appetite  for...books. Intrigued, PROUIX takes the parcel. He opens the book and peers under the false cover. His face turns bright red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, how could you...have you  actually read this volume?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've memorized it. Would you like me  to recite? She giggles. PROUIX joins in, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There comes a time in a young lady's  life when she has to cast book's  aside, and learn from experience. SIMONE cocks her head at a coy angle:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a challenge:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, Monsieur, requires a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER is paying a visit to MADELEINE and MADAME LECLER The OLD WOMAN sips tea; MADELEINE folds laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've good news; I hope you'll agree. THE TWO WOMEN look to him, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've found employment for you both  with the Widow Rougemont in town. MADELEINE's alarmed; she doesn't want to leave Charenton. COULMIER does his best to keep the news upbeat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have your own cottage on the  grounds, and ten francs a month to  use as you please.
MADAME LECLERC nearly drops her teacup in delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're more than a priest; you're an  angel! Ain't he, Maddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because of the Marquis, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In part, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not the man who's cast a shadow  here. COULMIER knows what she says is true, but can't admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor's a respected man, a friend  of the court--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been to see the Marquis  for ages. And I won't--ever again--I  swear it. I won't speak to him, I  won't even utter his name--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a promise you can truly keep? She can't answer. COULMIER glances at MADAME LECLERC; her blindness gives him license to touch MADELEINE. He stroke her cheek; she presses his hand tightly against her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charenton has changed; it's not safe  for you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've you to look after me, haven't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place looks immaculate down to the last detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Most Esteemed Dr. Royer-Collard. At  long last, your Chateau is complete."
Through it, we see PROUIX, sitting in an open dressing go at a small cherry-wood secretary, proof-reading a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You'll find everything in its  assigned place."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The chintz draperies, the English  bell pulls, even the ivory door stops.  Only one detail is missing..." He emits a series of staccato moans followed by a long si SIMONE rises from between the ARCHITECT's legs. Her camis is askew, and her face is aglow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...your wife."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm no fool. A prison's  still a prison, even with Chinese  silk and chandeliers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "By the time you read this, we'll be  long gone; bound for England or points  beyond..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him--if he uncovers our  whereabouts--you'll slit your wrists  with a razor, and I'll plunge a hat- pin through my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genuinely touched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do that, rather than forsake  our love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But tell him I would. PROUIX's face falls. SIMONE's leans over and whispers in ear to console him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign it quickly.  Then you can ravish  me again. On linens for which he so  dearly paid.
PROUIX rebound with puppy-dog eagerness; he traces her li with his forefinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, on the satin twill...and then,  I beg you, on the bear-skin rug in  his study...and finally...as a  crowning gesture....we'll leave  puddles of love on the Peruvian  marble! Slowly, he inserts his finger all the way into her mouth. SIMONE sucks on it happily, like an infant nursing a teat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD walks up the impressive steps to the front  door, GAILLON at his heels. Stuck there--with a quill pen letter.  He plucks it, glances back at GAILLON, then star to read. His iron jaw begins to quake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes through the grand foyer, up the magnificent  staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying haphazardly in the center of the mattress: A Ladies Garden of Verse. ROYER-COLLARD makes a grab for it, only turn it over and discover its true contents. A primal cry rises in ROYER-COLLARD's throat. Savagely he rips into th pages with his bare hands, shredding them. THE MARQUIS' w flutter down like snow. They fill the screen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP: THE MARQUIS' FACE, as the words trickle down, t gradually disappear. His hair is sopping wet. His skin is pale blue, lined with purple veins. His teeth chatter, an he sputters for air. A loud CRANK, and he disappears from the frame with a start.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: The Marquis, strapped into the calming chair in the dunge GAILLON flips the lever.  THE MARQUIS rises from the frig bath; his expression is one of distilled fury.  He cries ferociously--to an UNSEEN PRESENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show your face! I've a right to see  my Inquisitor!  You've an aptitude  for torture I really quite admire-- we're cut from the same cloth, you  and I-- GAILLON gives another YANK, dunking THE MARQUIS again wit loud SPLASH. When he rises, THE MARQUIS hisses at GAILLON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It thrills you, doesn't it, to hurt  me thus? Look, you're solid as bone,  you're straining your trousers-- Another dunk, another splash. THE MARQUIS tries a new tac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop, I beg you!  I'll write dainty  stories! Odes to Virtue! If even  your God will forgive me, so should  you-- Dunk, splash. Now, THE MARQUIS roars:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the recipient of THE MARQUIS' spleen: peering thro the peephole, ROYER-COLLARD. In his eyes, some small meas of vengeance, sated. He slips out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE tosses and turns on the straw mattress she shar with her mother; perspiration plasters her hair to her fa Finally, she crawls out of bed, and slips out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torches light the way as MADELEINE moves down the corrido In the distance, we hear sounds previously unassociated w Charenton: the clanking of chains and the wailing of inma Perhaps GAILLON thunders down the hall, PITOU and DAUPHIN under each arm. At last, MADELEINE reaches the ABBE's  quarters, and raps on his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER draws on his robe, and cracks the door. MADELEIN slithers inside. He whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be calling on me, not  at this hour; suppose the  nightwatchman saw you, or the cook-- COULMIER sticks his head out the door, glancing to and fr then closes it tightly; he can't disguise his pleasure at seeing MADELEINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't turn us out, Abbe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Turn you out?" Somewhere, a patient wails in the night; another pounds h head against stone. All Charenton rumbles with discontent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sin against God for me to  refuse your kindness. But my heart's  held fast here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By whom? The Marquis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a rueful little  laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother's not half so blind as you. COULMIER understands the magnitude of MADELEINE's confess he also knows--all to well--its futility:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine, I....there are certain  things...feelings...we must not voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They incite us to act. In ways we  should not...cannot...a lesson the  Marquis would do well to learn. MADELEINE's so full of feeling that she starts to cry.   COULMIER reaches for her, and takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. Shhh. You mustn't... He feels her body against his own. His resistance spent,  they kiss. Abruptly, he pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to your room. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What've I done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come back, not tonight, not  again--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll hate me now, won't you? With no choice before him, he lies:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Madeleine, as a  parishioner--as a child of God-- COULMIER swings open the door. He summons all his willpow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My vows are mine and mine alone. So  are my failings. Forgive me. Stung, MADELEINE stifles a sob. She gives COULMIER a fina hurt look and slips out the door. Alone now, COULMIER tri to walk off his arousal, circling the room like a prisone in a cage. Impulsively, he goes to the door and opens it  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees the figure of a GIRL, lurking in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine-- Furtively, the GIRL steps forward; it's CHARLOTTE. She sh him an accusatory glare; COULMIER ducks back inside, his  heart pounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE, still smarting from COULMIER's rejection, walk down the gloomy, forbidding hall. She stops. Somewhere de within, MADELEINE makes a sudden, irrevocable decision. S abruptly turns around, heading toward the MARQUIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER kneels on the floor of his cell, his vestments  lowered around his waist. He prays.  Clutched tightly in hand, a braided scourge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Lead us not into temptation..." He cracks the whip against his bare back; it leaves a wic stripe. His body flinches, but his voice doesn't waver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...but deliver us from evil..." And another crack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE watches as VALCOUR turns a corner. Once the coa is clear, she scrambles for her key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slips inside. She holds up her candle and--crumpled i the corner--THE MARQUIS. He glances at her, a wounded ani

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've taken your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They decreed me a savage, and now  they have made me one. MADELEINE--embarrassed--abruptly turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you've seen a man naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only been described to me. In  your books. She rallies and turns to squint at him, seated in the glo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say, in your novels you stoke  the most unrealistic expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're far crueler than I, my sweet. MADELEINE tosses her shawl to him which he fastens like a skirt around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Abbe's sending me away.  He fears  for me here, what with the likes of  you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be fooled, Madeleine!  He fears  for himself.  He's like a man  starving, and you--ha!--you're like  a pork chop dolloped with heavy cream--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a man of God; he's true to his  vows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First and foremost, he's a MAN. You  remind him of that fact, and he  resents you for it. MADELEINE's brow darkens; she knows it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see, my sweet? In us, they  see their own appetites, stripped  bare.  And so we are reviled; we are  beaten, we are trounced, we are  ridiculed, and we are silenced. (past hopelessness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to be done? It's the artist's  lot. In MADELEINE, something stirs. An idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It needn't be; not if you've another  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you propose I write it? With  dust, upon the air?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could whisper it through the  walls of your cell. MADELEINE sees THE MARQUIS perk, ever-so-slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes; that's it! A final volley from  us both!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night, whisper a new tale  to your neighbor, Cleante.  He'll  whisper it to his neighbor Dauphin,  who'll whisper it to his neighbor  Franval---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting the idea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --who'll whisper it to Bouchon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --whose cell lies next to the linen  cabinet! There, armed with a quill  of my own, I'll commit it to paper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with real momentum  now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! You shall. Of course you shall--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (practically squealing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tale more horrible than all the  rest combined!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something to make the angels weep,  and the Saints to gasp for air...    He kisses her fingers, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice your handwriting, my lovely.   So you'll do my words justice. She nods, even as her eyes fill with happy tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rumble of thunder from overhead; a storm is approaching MADELEINE tugs a sheet off the line. Standing behind it,  COULMIER. MADELEINE--startled--gives a little cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine-- Angrily, tugs down the next sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't fear the Marquis' sway on  me.  You fear your own.
COULMIER reaches to take her by the arm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd grant me a final favor, I'd  like the chance to explain myself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nasty, but tinged  with hurt:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come any closer, Abbe. God's  watching. She grabs her basket by both handles and--insolently--ski COULMIER and heads inside. COULMIER starts to follow, but response she hurries her step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky cracks open with a deafening sound. Lightning cra Rain begins to pelt the stone walls of Charenton. INT. THE LINEN PANTRY - A SHORT TIME LATER. MADELEINE swings open the door and sets down her laundry  basket. She lights a small wall sconce, filling the room  with an orange glow. She closes the door behind her. Next she clears a space for herself on a small sewing table,  pushing aside a pin-cushion, bolts of thread, and a heavy pair of scissors. She lifts a sheet off the top of the ba Under it, a stack of parchment, an inkwell, and a quill. removes each item, one-by-one. An EYEBALL watches her eve move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON's hunched on the floor, peering through the old w door. A belt hoists his sack-cloth trousers above his wai He's been dislodging bricks from the interior of his cell wall to reveal the hidden door to the pantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MARQUIS dislodges a small stone from the wall, and pe into the neighboring cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst...Cleante! Are you there? ARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEANTE is a study in nervous tics; his eyes blink, his e wiggle, and his mouth quivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marquis? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fuck's sake, who else would it  be? The witching hour's arrived;  you've alerted the others, yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no longer a man! I awoke to  discover I'd turned into a sparrow! CLEANTE begins to warble. THE MARQUIS stares through the  wall at CLEANTE, eye-to-eye. His words are hypnotic:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, I awoke to discover I'd  turned into a cat. If you don't do  as I say, I'll sink my little fangs  into your drumsticks, and suck the  marrow straight out of your bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trembling convulsively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your service, Count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now give the signal. CLEANTE lets loose with a piercing trill, to alert his  compatriots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sparks to the sound; at last, it's time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up from his reading, candle in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even he registers the whistle with a low grunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE whispers a tiny prayer, clutching the ink pot t her bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so we begin... With a certain improvisatory relish, THE MARQUIS begins t spin his tale:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Our story concerns the prostitute  Fanchon, whom Nature equipped with a  tight and downy fissure between her  thighs, and the most finely cleft  ass ever moulded by the hand of  God..." Through the chink, THE MARQUIS hears CLEANTE moaning, eve so softly, masturbating to the tale. THE MARQUIS barks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEANTE springs into action, rushing to the opposite side the room and perching on a chair. He whispers through a h by a beam in the ceiling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Fanchon was a prostitute with a  tight and downy fissure between her  thighs..." He starts to forget the phrase; THE MARQUIS hisses from a the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the most finely cleft ass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under his breath, THE MARQUIS frets:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My glorious prose, filtered through  the minds of the insane? (a sudden, consoling  thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows? They might improve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAUPHIN crouches, listening, as CLEANTE transmits the wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...and the most finely cleft ass  ever moulded by the hand of God!" He scurries across the room to relay the words to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...a harlot, she was, name of  Fanchon, with a downy fissure and a  heavenly ass..." FRANVAL lopes over to the wall he shares with BOUCHON. He removes a small sculptured crucifix, revealing a gap in t stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psst...Bouchon....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON' still busy peeping on MADELEINE, heedless of FRA

dialogues.speaker: ...BOUCHON
dialogues.text: Distracted, BOUCHON turns in the direction of FRANVAL's v FRANVAL has to whisper loudly so the story carries:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...'S about a harlot named Fanchon,  with a downy fissure and a heavenly  ass...." BOUCHON'S LIPS CURL IN A GRIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouchon! You've something for me,  haven't you? Almost shyly, BOUCHON ekes out the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...a downy fissure, and a heavenly  ass..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must remember each word, exactly  as it's told to you. Yes? Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One day, Fanchon's first client was  a surgeon.  He ran his fingers across  her naked skin, pulling apart folds  of flesh, inspecting each and every  follicle..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One day, Fanchon was visited by a  surgeon. He ran his fingers across  her naked skin, pulling apart folds  of flesh, inspecting follicles..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One day, a surgeon came to visit  Fanchon. He felt her naked skin,  pulling at her folds, fingering every  hair..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One day, a surgeon came to visit...   feeling her naked skin...pulling at  her folds..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON gives a low giggle; it's a naughty story, this on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "One day, a surgeon...ran his fingers  over her naked skin...her naked  skin...naked..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE writes as fast as she can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yes, I've got that bit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savouring the words)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What shall I ready?" asked Fanchon.   "My mouth, my ass or my succulent  oyster?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What shall I ready?" asked Fanchon.   "My mouth, my ass or my succulent  oyster?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What'll it be?" she asked. "My mouth,  my ass or my succulent oyster?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My mouth," she asked, "My ass or my  succulent oyster?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON's really in the spirit now:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Which hole? My mouth, my ass or my  succ...succ...succ... succulent  oyster?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE scripts the words "succulent oyster."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now THE MARQUIS is seized by inspiration; this story is v Truly vile!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "None!" cried the surgeon, brandishing  his scalpel. "I'll carve new orifices  where...there...were...none...before!" He laughs, delighted at his own powers of invention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEANTE claps his hands, rapturous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "None!" cried the surgeon, brandishing  his scalpel. "I'll carve new orifices  where there were none before!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAUPHIN's so excited by the tale, he slaps his bald head  with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "None!" cried the surgeon. "I'll  carve new orifices where there were  none before!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANVAL's aroused; he adjusts the rising staff in his  trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "None!" he cried. "I'll carve new  orifices where there were none  before!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON removes one brick, then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'll carve new...new...NEW...orifices  where there were none before!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE scribes the word "carve."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face pours sweat; he's in a state of orgasmic excitem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "With that, Fanchon expelled a scream  so extravagantly pitched, that the  surgeon was obliged to tear out her  tongue---"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beside himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "With that, Fanchon expelled a scream  so extravagantly pitched, that the  surgeon was obliged to tear out her  tongue---"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhilarated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "With that, she screamed so loud  that the surgeon was obliged to tear  out her tongue---"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (red-faced)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She screamed--so long and so loud--  that the surgeon was obliged to tear  out her tongue---"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON whips off his belt; his trousers crumple to the f He hooks the buckle over the head of a nail in the hinge. Next, he twists the belt around his hand for leverage and begins to pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rife with guilty  pleasure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She screamed, so he felt he should-- he felt he ought--to tear out her  tongue---"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE wets the tip of her quill with her own tongue, then transcribes the same word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To seal the wound, he took a poker  from the fire--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...a poker...he took a poker from  the fire..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAUPHIN stares, still hypnotized by FRANVAL'S candle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A poker from the fire! From the  fire...from the fire...the fire, the  fire, the fire!" He reaches through the hole and steals the candlestick; T wax scalds his hand; he hurls it onto his bed with a yelp The mattress bursts into flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANVAL's left high and dry; coitus interruptus indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dauphin? What's the next bit? You  must tell me the next bit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, sounds start to grow; DAUPHIN, hollering "fire"  from his cell.  Other LUNATICS--agitated--pounding on the cell floors. BOUCHON wrests another nail from the hinge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a frightened whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. The words. Tell me the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke pours out from beneath DAUPHIN's cell, and into the hall. VALCOUR--several guards in tow--races down the corr to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADELEINE hears their footsteps rushing past, and the ris cry of "fire!" She cracks the door slightly and peers out transfixed by what she sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances to her right, in time to see VALCOUR and his tearing open DAUPHIN's door. Smoke pours forth. The GUARD are disoriented; it stings their eyes, and fills their lu They stumble; VALCOUR coughs, then doubles over. As he  wretches, DAUPHIN clips the keys from his belt and slips  outside. MADELEINE senses that all hell is about to break loose; s closes the door, and turns pack to retrieve her parchment and tell-tale quill. She glances up to see--with horror-- that BOUCHON's door has been dismantled. She stands and b away, until she bumps into a HULKING FIGURE. She turns. I BOUCHON, sewing scissors in hand. MADELEINE tries to calm him, her voice tremulous:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember your manners, Bouchon, like  the Abbe says. But his leer tells the truth. She tries to dodge him, but with a lunge--he's upon her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MARQUIS recognizes the howling voice down the hall. His face goes white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine...MADELEINE!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a trance-like state, CLEANTE continues to mimic the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine! Madeleine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine! Madeleine! Madeleine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAUPHIN runs up and down the hall, VALCOUR's keychain in  hand, unlocking cell after cell. The LUNATICS pour out. They pick up the sing-song cry, screaming Madeleine's nam at a hideous pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine! Madeleine! Madeleine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER's awakened by the sounds of the LUNATICS crying  "Madeleine! Madeleine!" He starts pulling on his vestment with trembling hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER rushes down the hall and glances into MADELEINE' QUARTERS. MADAME LECLERC lies alone in the bed she shares with her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine-- MADAME LECLERC stirs, reaching out for her child, patting the lumpy mattress, hoping to touch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy? Where are you now? Maddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A burning pillow cascades down, trailing straw. As COULMI bounds downstairs, he catches sight of a figure: a  CHAMBERMAID, rushing past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine-- He follows her, dodging MADMEN brandishing broomsticks,  bedsheets, and the splintered remnants of furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHAMBERMAID enters the infirmary; COULMIER races afte her. He has to fight his way past Charenton's MOST DIRE C who lurch toward him in the smokey haze like zombies.

An aging MADMEN with elephantiasis; a WITHERED OLD CRONE a stolen nun's habit with a hideous grin, her hands thrus under her own skirts; ONE AILING MADMAN carries ANOTHER  through the murk; a demented pieta. In the background,  curtains blaze. COULMIER catches sight of the CHAMBERMAID. He makes a bee line for her, grabs her by the arm, and swirls her around It's not MADELEINE at all, but CHARLOTTE. COULMIER can't  help it; his face betrays dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her fault the Devil's unleashed  himself upon us...it's her fault... COULMIER thrusts CHARLOTTE aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine! Madeleine! From outside, a horrible scream. COULMIER's eyes fill wit alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD empties the last dregs from his wine bottle pitiful little puddle in the bottom of his glass. Before  him, the asylum record books in grave disarray. GAILLON  lounges in a near-by chair. As the DIN of the RIOT grows  around them, they exchange a look; one that says "We knew this would happen. How could it not?" EXT. CHARENTON - TERRACE. COULMIER, soaked in the rain, searches the courtyard. All around him, WARDS--like pagans--are stripping off their  clothes, dancing in the storm. PITOU rides atop GUERIN's  shoulders; LOUISON tries to beat him off with an andiron. The scream again; COULMIER whirls around, expecting to se MADELEINE. Again, his hopes are dashed. It's MICHETTE, pi to the wall, set upon by a group of LASCIVIOUS WARDS, the limbs all intertwined in an orgiastic frenzy. ONE BESTIAL MAN turns to look at COULMIER, his eyes wild, scrap of MICHETTE's clothing dripping from his mouth, lik flap of flesh. COULMIER dives in to rescue her, but--instead--he's set u by more MISCREANTS, who tug at his robes and paw at his h like creatures turning on their Master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, the insistent, demonic chanting of Madeleine' name.  GAILLON bursts from the office and makes for the  stairs; ROYER-COLLARD strides out after him, glancing  imperiously this way and that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a desperate howl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still fending off MADMEN, COULMIER bellows at the sky:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he passes, ROYER-COLLARD hears a scuffle from within. He pauses, and reaches for the knob. Just then, he hears  COULMIER and THE MARQUIS in the distance, each crying out for Madeleine. From the pantry, her Voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbe? Is that you?...He means to  kill me...save me as you have  before...I beg you...I'm sorry for  all that I said...please...oh,  please... ROYER-COLLARD's face calcifies with hate. From inside, a  heart-piercing scream.  He feels a surge of victory in hi chest, and lifts his hand from the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinders fall from above. Poised along the stair, ORVOLLE, VALCOUR and GAILLON. They're passing pails of water upwar in an effort to quell the flames.  ROYER-COLLARD joins th line, passing a sloshing bucket from ORVOLLE to VALCOUR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly now! Altogether men, as one! ORVOLLE looks at him, surprised to see the aloof DOCTOR  suddenly so pro-active.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICKLY! Before it reaches the rafters  on the upper floors-- GAILLON gazes at his BOSS with glowing admiration. Coming down the stairs--disoriented in the smoke and the melee-- MADAME LECLERC. With one hand, she clings to the railing. With the other, she grasps at the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy! Where are you, child? Maddy! The LUNATIC QUARTET--in their night drawers, their faces  blackened with ash--trundle after her, playing a jaunty t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER--his cassock torn and soaked through, his face  scratched--races down the stairs THE MARQUIS, meanwhile,  screams bloody murder from the peephole in his cell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out your morons! Let me loose! COULMIER catches his eye, and shoots an accusatory glare. "You've played a part in this, haven't you?" he seems to asking. THE MARQUIS turns silent, even stony, staring bac at COULMIER with lethal eyes. COULMIER moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER races through the room. He sees the dismantled d lifted off its hinges, lying sideways against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER's eyes dart feverishly about; the linens are dre in blood. He glances down at his feet; he sees a few piec of parchment. He picks up a sheet. The last sentence read "tear out her tongue" before trailing off the page. He  recognizes the curve of MADELEINE's script. His heart pounding, he moves toward the laundry room,  terrified of what he might find. Underfoot, a growing poo of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the far end of the laundry room, BOUCHON, dripping wet his lower lip quivering like a naughty child, recedes int the shadows.  Meanwhile, MADAME LECLERC emerges from the  smoke, clutching her stirring stick like a pike for  protection. THE SOUND OF WATER SLOSHING.
She turns, her face full of dread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water cascades down the sides of the vat. MADAME LECLERC  climbs atop her pedestal, inserts her stick into the brew and begins to stir. COULMIER stands, dizzy, the room spinning around him in a mad whirl that becomes... THE SWIRLING WATERS OF THE LAUNDRY VAT. Rising to the sur like a phantom from the mist, MADELEINE.  Her skin is  translucent blue. As her corpse rolls in the water, we se that it is riddled with scissor gashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun turns the horizon a feverish red. In the distance cock crows. ORVOLLE and LOUISON nail wooden planks across Charenton's windows; WORKMEN fortify the grounds with  barriers. The asylum stands, like an injured beast, too  obstinate--and now, too cruel--to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HORSEMAN waits, but there's no one to greet him with manuscript. A final, lingering look and--dejected--he tur to leave. His horse rears up on its hind legs in distress then gallops away through the morning mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open, and light illuminates BOUCHON. As s as he sees VALCOUR and GAILLON in the doorway, he scuttle under his cot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now. Don't be shy. We've a nice  surprise just waiting for you... BOUCHON peers out from beneath the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweat trickles in tiny rivulets down BOUCHON's forehead. hear the CREAK of HINGES; a metal cage snaps over his fac

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: VALCOUR and GAILLON, soldering shut the iron dummy. BOUCH eyes bulge as he's encased--forever--in a sarcophagus mad of steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD closes the door to the dungeon, and cracks knuckles with barely-controlled fury.  COULMIER sits, his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, we mustn't blame Bouchon;  he's merely one of Nature's  experiments, gone awry. No discipline.  No conscience. No morality. He rears up from behind his desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, it is our duty to provide  those things on his behalf. Is it  not? COULMIER raises his head. His eyes are red from crying, b he's resolved not to lose his temper before the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you say, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was so impressed with the Marquis'  tale that he chose to re-enact it,  yes?  Upon a certain chambermaid. COULMIER nods. ROYER_COLLARD blithely sticks the knife in and gives it a turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you'll be so kind as to remind  me of her name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, Doctor, don't make me say  it.

dialogues.speaker: HER NAME, ABBE.
dialogues.text: COULMIER chokes back a sob and manages:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeleine. THE DOCTOR tosses MADELEINE's bloody manuscript onto the  center of the desk, and lays into COULMIER savagely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me: when you're called before  God, how will you answer for  Madeleine's death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER blazes down the hall, torch in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER climbs down a spiral stair built along the param of an enormous pit. In its center, a LUNATIC, crouched in feral pose. He wears a heavy iron collar with four long  chains, each strapped to a different wall in the room. He longer resembles a man; he looks like a beast, trapped in stone cage; it's THE MARQUIS. He peers into the gloom wit wolverine eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer! THE MARQUIS blurts, defensively:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm to be blamed now, am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your words drove Bouchon to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For fuck's sake, Abbe! What am I to  do? Police my readers as you police  me? Suppose one of your precious  wards had attempted to walk on water  and drowned? Would you condemn the  Bible? I think not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An innocent child is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many authors are denied the  gratification of a concrete response  to their work. I am blessed, am I  not?
This flagrant disregard for MADELEINE cuts through COULMI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no secret that you loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's rich--coming from her  lapdog--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the longing in your eye--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --that was lust--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the passion in your heart-- THE MARQUIS grabs his own crotch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't confuse one organ with another--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, because I felt it myself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're no stranger to rape, Marquis;  and yet with her, you cooed. You  courted. You begged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was it you never took her by  force?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's to say I did not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it impotence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it must've been love-- The MARQUIS chokes on COULMIER's last word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We inspected the body, Marquis.  She  died a virgin. A stunned pause. The MARQUIS cracks--a tiny cry at first, which erupts into genuine sobbing.  He sinks to his knees and claws the dirt with his hands. Finally, he whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her a proper burial. In the  churchyard, at my expense. Do not  inter her sweet body in the same  ground as the devils who inhabit  this accursed place. Pause, and then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your terrible secret, revealed. You're  a man, after all. Suddenly--savagely--THE MARQUIS spits in his face. COULMIER wipes away the indignity. He stands, severe now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that remains now is your  punishment. THE MARQUIS extends his arm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dare you. Stab my flesh. Which one  of us will bleed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, we'll cut out your tongue.
For once, THE MARQUIS' balks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALCOUR manacles it to an operating table. CLOSE UP: THE MARQUIS' RIGHT HAND. VALCOUR cuffs it, too. Next, GAILLON splays the MARQUIS'  feet, and clamps them in irons. He buckles leather restra around the MARQUIS' torso.  The MARQUIS cranes his head, glances at the table beside him.  On it, primitive medica instruments, laid out ominously in a row. A RAT scurries  across them. GAILLON sharpens his blade on a stone. COULMIER watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've opium to numb the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crisply:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our intention here is punitive. If  we numb the pain, what's the point? The MARQUIS twists his neck to find the PRIEST:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbe de Coulmier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you'll grant me a final word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. The MARQUIS' eyes flash with malevolence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would that I were so easily silenced. COULMIER wrenches his hand free. GAILLON raises his scalp and looks to COULMIER for permission to begin. COULMIER nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From within, an animal cry. COULMIER walks down the corri away from the grisly proceedings. On his face, a tiny fli perhaps--somewhere deep down in his soul--he feels the th of victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR is knee-deep in paperwork; COULMIER bursts int the room. He slams a glass jar down on the DOCTOR's desk. Bobbling in alcohol, THE MARQUIS' tongue, so long and  serpentine it's wrapped around a dowel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, my. You have exceeded my  expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the patient faring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poorly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you? It must've been an ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the first man God has asked  to shed blood in His name. I will  not be the last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sleep soundly tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faltering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. Plainly put, I never expect  to sleep again. INT. CHARENTON - CHAPEL - LATER. On a slab in the center of the chapel lies MADELEINE, dra in white silk. A CREAK as the door opens. COULMIER approa the body, and places a wreath of newly-cut flowers at  MADELEINE's head. He kneels to pray. In a voice choking w emotion, he mumbles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In nomine patris et filii et spiritu  santu..." A bead of sweat trickles down COULMIER's face. He takes t hem of MADELEINE's death shroud, and wipes the droplet aw The shroud slides off MADELEINE's face. She lies dormant. Her skin is rosy, and her lips are slightly parted. Unabl to resist, COULMIER tugs the shroud off further, exposing her shoulders. COULMIER marvels at her breasts, sloping  beneath the fabric. His heart pounds like a kettle drum. Impulsively, COULMIER pulls the shroud all the way off.  MADELEINE lies before him, flawless. There are no wounds, sign of the gore which accompanied her death. He gazes at her with an almost child-like wonder. Slowly, circles the body.  Tentatively, he reaches out his finger touch her lips; to trace the white porcelain of her  collarbone; perhaps even graze his hand across her breast He hesitates, then he leans down to kiss her. It's an alm chaste moment, but it stuns her awake. MADELEINE lives. COULMIER leaps back, alarmed. But MADELE wraps her arms around his neck. She returns the kiss,  passionately. It's all the encouragement COULMIER needs; he crawls astr her on the slab.  Soon, he's running his hands in and out her rounded thighs, feeling each hollow, each moist crevi His touch grows from gentle to frantic as desire mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Roughly, COULMIER parts her legs. She grabs his back, her nails digging into his skin, as though she were hanging o for dear life. With a guttural sound--his Id, at last  unleashed--COULMIER grimaces with pleasure and enters her One savage thrust; then two. His eyes light on the crucif hanging across from him on the wall. ANGLE ON: THE CRUCIFIX. CHRIST's forehead is pierced through with nettles, and bl flows in tiny rivers down his face. He stares at COULMIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who shudders and glances down at the body beneath him.
COULMIER's POV: The lifeless corpse of MADELEINE bearing wounds which killed her, desecrated, on the cold marble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER's eyes bolt open. He lurches upright, and tries stay the bile rising in his throat. A loud knocking at hi door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abbe! You'd best come quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALCOUR and COULMIER move down the hall like bullets down the barrel of a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALCOUR unlocks the wrought-iron gate, and they enter. Gasping for breath, VALCOUR covers his face with a  handkerchief. He raises his lantern. In the din--flickeri orange--words. Everywhere, words. On the ceiling. Written the floor. Etched on the walls.  It's as if the TWO MEN h stumbled into the tomb of Tutankhamen, with its glyphic t or a Sanskrit monument covered in symbols.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spat into his own filth. Made  himself a kind of paint. COULMIER stares, awe-struck. He can't help but be impress the effort is nothing less than Herculean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God. COULMIER glances down to the pit's base. There, the MARQU lies, his face pale and his breathing shallow. In spite o his decrepitude, there's the look of triumph in his eyes. look which says, "I persevered." COULMIER rushes to him. He feels for his heart-beat; it's faint. The MARQUIS tries to speak, but the soiled bandage across his mouth prevents him. He can only murmur. COULMI calls up to VALCOUR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Free his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mustn't do that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must grant him his last rites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't take my orders from you; not  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd deny a dying man his salvation? Sullenly, VALCOUR tosses his knife down to the ground, th recedes into darkness. COULMIER tenderly cradles the MARQ head in his lap, and mops his brow. He takes the knife an delicately snips the bandage; it falls away. Slowly, painfully, the MARQUIS parts his lips. He coughs air. He tries to speak, but--sans his tongue--he can't fo words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh...shhh... (praying softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Heavenly Father.  Prove Your  infinite mercy, and open Your gates  to this man, no less Your child than  any other. COULMIER kisses the MARQUIS' forehead. He makes a painful admission for the first time:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is...in each of us...such  beauty... and such abomination.   No...man...is ...exempt. The MARQUIS tries to smile. COULMIER smiles, too, his eye brimming with tears. The old affection between the two me is evident, even now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive him. Forgive us all. COULMIER places the small ivory crucifix of his rosary ov the MARQUIS's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There now. Kiss the cross. A flicker of life in the MARQUIS's eyes; a remnant of his old self. He opens his mouth savagely, and grabs the cruc in his teeth.

COULMIER tries to wrest it out, but the MARQUIS clamps do tighter with his teeth. The chain breaks; rosary beads go streaming across his face, bouncing across the stone floo With concerted effort--almost gagging--the MARQUIS swallo COULMIER watches, appalled. We see the shape of the cross in relief--as it inches down the MARQUIS' gullet, beneath his skin. Finally--with a last gulp--the crucifix goes do The MARQUIS has ingested Christ. THE MARQUIS' pupils roll back into his lids. He stares at COULMIER with a lifeless gaze. COULMIER finally breaks; h lets loose with a primal cry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAUPHIN is shackled to the wall; his skull has been treph and bears the trace of his own barbaric surgery. He hears the scream, echoing down the corridor. His face  contorts in empathetic pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PITOU desperately covers his ears with his hands, but he  can't ward off the sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLEANTE--sitting atop a crudely-fashioned perch--hears hi Master, and lets loose with an urgent whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOUCHON peers out from his human cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COULMIER's whole face contorts in pain and rage; a man cr deep from within the Belly of the Beast.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD.
dialogues.text: He has all the optimism--the idealism--that COULMIER once brought to the halls of Charenton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD greets ABBE DU MAUPAS, a youthful priest wi a face filled with optimism; he carries a small traveling valise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Charenton, Abbe du Maupas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pleased to have the new post,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that our endowment has  shriveled to a mere pittance; we're  the laughing stock of all France.  But--on a happier note-- The DOCTOR smiles, and pats the ABBE jovially on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the hospital is now in my sole  command. ABBE DU MAUPAS all but runs to keep pace with the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here each man must work for his keep. ROYER-COLLARD swings open the gate to the work-room for t ABBE DU MAUPAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is abuzz with the sound of industry; the bowels Charenton have been transformed into a veritable publishi house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Charenton Press, Abbe. ROYER-COLLARD waves toward a bank of printer's desks, whe a few PATIENTS--FRANVAL among them--are setting type, the fingers blackened by printer's ink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The compulsive inmates set the type-- He gestures toward sewing and binding tables, where DAUPH among others--bind the books, their aprons sticky with gl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and the listless ones do the  binding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's remarkable, Doctor. The patients  are so subdued; so docile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've the satisfaction only a hard  day's labor can provide. CLEANTE turns the handle on a giant press. PITOU plucks o the pages--one-by-one--and hangs them on lines to dry. ABBE DU MAUPAS notices the title page: Opus Sadicum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. The Marquis de  Sade? You're actually publishing his  novels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since his unfortunate death,  there's been a surge of interest in  his work. I'll use the profits to  restore Charenton to her former glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Doctor. It's CHARLOTTE.  No longer a common chambermaid, she look resplendent now in a dress befitting a young woman of sta perhaps a future DOCTOR's bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've a meeting with Herr Becker at  four o'clock.  He wants to publish a  Swiss edition--on gilded paper, bound  in calfskin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank-you, Charlotte. CHARLOTTE turns coquettish; she and the DOCTOR exchange a telling smile; theirs is more than a professional allianc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure. Truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a look at page seventy-four;  I've turned the corner down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALCOUR and GAILLON load crates of books onto wagons. MICHETTE--idling by the well--watches as the COACHMEN dep charging toward Paris and beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROYER-COLLARD escorts the young ABBE on a tour, passing  through the PATIENT's WARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, everything's not as  harmonious as it seems. I hope you've  a strong constitution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My years tending the lepers at St.   Emilion steeled me for life's  grisliest offerings, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've still a few lone incurables.   Prone to violence, to perversion. They reach THE MARQUIS old cell; the peephole is open. ABBE DU MAUPAS steps forward to get a look at the MADMAN  inside; A FIGURE stands with his back to us. His hair is  long and unkept. The PATIENT speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're my successor. Yes? Slowly, the speaker turns around. It's COULMIER. The ABBE startled-- exchanges a look with ROYER-COLLARD; who is th haunted figure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My successor? COULMIER barks a scabrous laugh, then abruptly changes hi tone. He presses himself against the door, and implores D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Abbe, and listen well. He casts a sidelong glance in ROYER-COLLARD's direction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've stared into the face of evil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to the ABBE:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I've lived to tell the tale.   Now...for your own sake...let me  write it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibberish, my friend. He rants and  he raves-- COULMIER offers the DU MAUPAS a challenge, urging him to  defy ROYER-COLLARD:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prove you've an ounce of Christian  charity...Bring me parchment...ink...  and a quill. ABBE DU MAUPAS looks to the DOCTOR; what should he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll do no such thing. This patient  poses a grave danger, to himself and  to others. With lightning speed, COULMIER reaches through the peepho grabbing ROYER-COLLARD by the collar. He yanks him, hard, against the door, strangling him with his own cravatte. T DOCTOR's face starts turning purple. ABBE DU MAUPAS pauses for a moment; who should he honor? His employer, or the mad prophet in the cell? Impulsively acts, loosening COULMIER's grip on the DOCTOR. ROYER-COLL gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see, Abbe? A pause, and then contemptuously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men are past redemption. ROYER-COLLARD straightens his collar and smooths back his hair, and starts striding back down the hall. ABBE DU MAU
queasy now--follows, but he can't help glancing back at  COULMIER.
